title.narrative: Local Governements Initiative on Climate Change
Local Governements Initiative on Climater Change

description.narrative: This conclusion on performance covers the year 2019 and also covers the entire project implementation to draw a overall conclusion on performance as Embassy is planning for a costed extension of the contribution. This GoB-EU-SIDA-UNDP-UNCDF is a multi-donor joint project in Bangladesh plans to promote local action on climate change adaptation at scale. This project was initially developed as a concept together by EU, SIDA, UNDP and UNCDF during 2014-2016 along with Local Government Division. EU developed the initial action fiche in consultation with UNDP, UNCDF and LGD. The action fiche titled “GCCA+ support for enhancing communities' resilience to climate change and related disasters” was approved in 2015 in European Parliament. In 2015, Sida joined in the design team and collectively developed the project titled “Local Government Initiative on Climate Change (LoGIC)”. In 2016, the project was signed with GoB with the financial support of GoB [BDT. 60,000,000 equivalent to USD 714285], EU [EURO 8,000,000 equivalent to USD 8,968,610], SIDA [SEK 85,000,000 equivalent to USD 9,902,144], UNCDF [USD 200,000] and UNDP [USD 200,000]. This project is implemented by UNDP and UNCDF and executed by Local Government Division. This project was initially designed for 4 years and now based on an independent assessment of EU and success of initial results, the project will be extended for another 30 months including a 6 months closing period. Government of Bangladesh aims to make this project a flagship project in developing a climate finance mechanism/model to deliver climate finance for the most vulnerable for building local resilience and therefore, titled the project as “Local Government Initiative on Climate Change (LoGIC)” following UNDP’s Joint Project Document Framework. This Conclusion on Performance has been prepared based on their annual reports, two field visits conducted and participation in different meetings and informal discussions with GoB, UNDP, UNCDF and Project staff. There has been no mid-term evaluation conducted for this project but end of 2019 EU conducted an assessment of the project. This assessment report also provides a basis for this CoP. With a delayed start, the projects accomplishment was very encouraging during 2018, 2019 and 2020. The project made a good progress towards establishing the approach and mechanisms. Some of the process and mehtodological achievements. Establishing the LoGIC Model as key delivery mechanism: In delivering climate finance to the most vulnerable, LoGIC project has emerged as a system by now. It has evolved as the model for identifying the most vulnerable, be it the household or the local government institutions (Union Parishads) and building resilience of them. Selection of 72 most vulnerable, physically disconnected and hardest-to-reach Union Parishads frequently affected by climate change variabilities and extremes (cyclone, sea level rise, salinity, flood and flash flood) is justified by national vulnerability ranking and hard-to-reach mapping, also acknowledged by the government and the other stakeholders. The rigorous project facilitation for carrying out the technical and participatory Community Risk Assessment (CRA) exercise founded the stone for designing the long-term strategic climate actions for the local government institutions (LGIs). Direct transfer of grants to these most vulnerable institutions for implementing project actions (through the Performance Based Climate Resilience Grants- PBCRG) and individual households (Community Resilience Fund- CRF) made the process roll. The effectiveness of the PBCRG and CRF, in curving down the climate vulnerability of the people in high risk areas, is yet to be measured. The LoGIC project enhanced the financial inclusion of the most vulnerable 17,000 women, who never thought of having access to the formal banking system. It has resulted in enhanced confidence among the women participants expressed, through their empowerment and internalizing meaningful ways in building resilience. The other co-benefit is the economic and social empowerment of the women. Women are not alone while they implement their adaptive livelihood options but are in groups with unified business plans to reduce their investment risks. This has created enthusiasm among the local stakeholders to engage in the process of resilience building. Now, the project needs to measure the impact of the PBCRG and CRF in reducing the climate change induced vulnerability of the most vulnerable people. When the system is established, it is important that the climate change attribution to the model is strengthened and ensure to proof the model in relation to the reduction of vulnerabilities in the next two years, so that it is scalable to more than 200 climate vulnerable UPs by 2023, with support from Green Climate Fund (GCF), Government of Bangladesh (GoB) and other non-vertical development partners. Mainstreaming adaptation (resilience) at the local level: LoGIC, through the CRA process, facilitated the participatory representation of the LGIs and the vulnerable communities. This helped brainstorm and identify their risks, which was prioritized at the planning exercise and incorporated in the long-term strategic plan of the Union Parishads (UPs). While UPs plan on building public goods for climate resilience (Risk Reduction Action Plan or RRAP), the community, on the other hand, plan for their own adaptive livelihood options (HHRRAP) for the same. Out of 72, targeted 71 UPs have received PBCRG grants (USD 1.79M) for implementing 228 climate change adaptation (CCA) schemes from their RRAP to create climate resilient public goods. There is potential for scaling up nature-based solutions with support from other sources such as philanthropists, development agencies, local community etc. to finance resilience and adaptation at the community level. On the other hand, 17,000 households of the community in 1,070 groups (based on interest, convenience, homogeneity choices, geographic proximity and communication) received USD 4.64M (2.88m disbursed in 2019, and 1.76m disbursed in 2018) and came up with 22 types of gender-responsive adaptive livelihood options. Adaptation actions at household level through CRF, who are most vulnerable and often left out from public goods benefits and widening the community scale adaptation micro-projects to reduce the vulnerability to climate change both followed the community risk assessment methodology. The vulnerable households and community within the Local Government (LG) constituencies interact in such a manner that ultimately ensure readiness to tackle climate hazards and strengthens the means for survival of the vulnerable community. However, such links require further strengthening and be informed from science-led predictions and scenarios of climate-induced risks. While, the project is well articulated in terms of participatory CRA, what will be more beneficial for climate change adaptation in this regard is a top-down method blended approach in promoting science-driven, informed participation of community in prioritizing their adaptation options at household and community levels. Potential for scaling-up of climate resilient/adaptive livelihoods: The core process of the selection of vulnerable households include (1) CRA and RRAP, (2) based on CRA, identification of two/three vulnerable wards from each UP, (3) conducting the census in these 147 wards, (4) identifying eligible beneficiaries (46,000) by minimum 0.5 vulnerability scores , (5) selection of relatively most vulnerable (26,000) households, with a primary shortlist (17000) and a waiting list (9000 HHs), (6) run a grievance register and redress mechanism and (7) finalize the 17000 HHs as final beneficiaries for the CRF. 98% of these HHs identified women member of the household as primary participant in the CRF and therefore, 16,660 are women as primary beneficiaries of CRF. These beneficiaries are pursuing 22 different types of climate resilient livelihoods in group enterprises, as a follow-up of the choices of the means of livelihoods and start-up grant support from the Project in two tranches. There are three (3) options to scale-up these livelihoods: (1) reaching to all eligible vulnerable groups (46,000 HHs) with different grants packages or reaching to all most vulnerable people (26,000 HHs) with common grant package; (2) scale-up of the most viable climate resilient livelihood options with formal credit market with higher environmental safeguard (i.e. crab fattening); and (3) facilitate private sector actors and co-design business case for scalable business opportunities on climate resilient means of livelihoods where vulnerable people secured income with backed-up skill training and social guarantee. A few examples include hydroponics, bio-flake, aquaponics, sunflower, crab-fattening, saline tolerant pulse, fruits and oil seeds production. Use of innovation for tracking and measuring adaptation: LoGIC demonstrates a comprehensive approach to ensure climate resilience. To keep records, track and measure adaptation, LoGIC has developed and put in place the state-of-the-art Accounting & Management Information Systems (MIS), Adaptation Tracking and Measuring (ATM) system for the project to make sure all the climate money are spent with rationale, the data are regularly entered and updated in the software which generates reports and tell stories of change in the field. Project’s M&E system inculcates all the information from the software and the database to create reports. Tapping upon innovation towards maximizing results, project has successfully trained 72 Union Parishads (LGI) Secretary on Accounting & MIS software. Field level project staffs have been provided hands-on training on filed-level data entry in changing context, future risks, use of grants etc. in the app-Tab-based ATM software. This approach has started to evolve as a transparent and accountable tool to measure climate change and adaptation data on the ground. Sustainable Development Goals: Progressing towards the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the Government of Bangladesh (GoB) has been pressing for more attention towards environmental issues. Of the 17 proposed SDGs, four (4) are related to climate change and environment and LoGIC contributes to or works towards Goals 1, 5, 10, 11, 13 and 16, i.e. contributing towards poverty eradiation, gender equality, sustainable communities, reduced inequalities, stronger institutions and climate change, broadly. LoGIC is working towards Goal 13.3, which is aimed to improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning through indicators (13.3.1 and 13.3.2). Likewise, with 13.2, i.e. to integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning. Although LoGIC has been working towards Goals 1, 5, 10, 11 and 16, only Goal 13 is included in the Strategic Results Framework. Specific achievements against goals are being studied and will be compiled for reporting. During the period, in early March 2020 a joint field visit was made to the project sites at Barguna district for five days. The joint mission was composed of EU, UNDP, UNCDF, GoB and Embassy of Sweden. Overall the findings were impressive. The third Project Steering Committee meeting took place virtually on 12 August 2020 chaired by the Senior Secretary, Local Government Division, Ministry of Local Government. Where relevant government ministry and departments participated. The meeting agreed and advocated for the top up and 2 years extension (up to 30 June 2023), expressed their commitment by agreeing to add 100 MBDT (about 1.2 MUSD) from GoB. Both EU and Embassy of Sweden participated in the meeting. Some major accomplishments 1. Community Risk Assessment (CRA) completed for 147 words in 72 Unions, 17,000 most vulnerable identified and listed in a through participatory manner. Among them 98% are female 2. Vulnerability identified for 147 words, 3. Climate resilient livelihood identified for 17,000 most vulnerable, transferred 1st tranche of Community Resilience Fund (CRF) through formal banking process. All these very remote area people have their bank account now with a formal bank. 4. Capacity enhancement activities done for all these 17,000 people 5. 243 climate resilient schemes implemented under the Performance Based Climate Resilient Grant (PBCRG) through Union Councils. Capacity enhancement of these Union parishad officials done 6. Information on Covid 19 disseminated to all the communities using different media and community well-being information collected from all the communities 7. 11 issues identified and ready for policy advocacy, so far 1 successful policy advocacy event completed with very good government buy inn.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 LOGIC - myndighetsinitativ för lokal klimatanpassning
COVID-19 Local Government Initiative on Climate Change (LoGIC)

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Programmet strävar efter att minska effekterna av klimatförändringar i Bangladesh. IPCC(International Panel on Climate Change) rankar Bangladesh som det sjätte mest utsatta landet i världen för klimatförändringar och det land som är mest utsatt för höjningen av havsnivån (undantaget små ö-riken). Förändringar av nederbörden förväntas leda till både fler och svårare översvämningar samt till perioder av torka i vissa områden. Inträngning av havsvatten samt fler och kraftigare cykloner ökar risken för förhöjd saltkoncentration i mark, floder och grundvattnet. Bangladesh regering uppskattar att de fem största naturkatastroferna sen 1998 har minskat BNP med 15%. Återkommande katastrofer har störst påverkar på den fattigaste delen av befolkningen och bidrar till en i vissa områden cementerad fattigdomsproblematik.
Bangladesh har varit ett föregångsland när det gällde att ta fram strategiska planer för att möta klimathotet (ex. National Adaptation Plan of Action - NAPA och Bangladesh Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan - BCCSAP) och att utveckla en nationell finansieringsmekanism för klimatanpassning (Bangladesh Climate Change Trust Fund - BCCTF) men trots att lokala initiativ för klimatanpassning identifieras som ett prioriterat område i både BCCSAP och NAPA så har endast en liten del av öronmärkta resursers implementerats av lokala myndigheter. Lokala klimatanpassningsprojekt som genomförs med en förankring hos befolkningen kan med relativt små medel minska utsattheten hos sårbara delar av befolkningen och medför ofta mindre risker än storskaliga infrastruktursatsningar.
UNDP och UNCDF har gemensamt utvecklat programmet (LoGIC) som avser att stärka lokala myndigheters kapacitet att integrera klimatanpassning i lokala utvecklingsplaner, förbättra nationella mekanismer för lokal klimatfinansiering och implementera klimatanpassningsåtgärder som har identifierats i samråd mellan lokala myndigheter och lokalbefolkningen. Civilsamhällets har en viktig funktion när det kommer till att mobilisera lokalbefolkningen och verka för transparens och ansvarsutkrävande gentemot lokal myndigheter och har därför en tydlig roll i programmet.
Programmet pågår under 48 månader och har en budget på c:a USD 20 milj., Sidas bidrag uppgår till 85 milj. kr vilket motsvarar ungefär hälften av programbudgeten och EU har redan beslutat om ett stöd på € 8 miljoner. Programmet är fullfinansierat men möjligheten finns att skala upp programmet om ytterligare givare skulle ansluta. Programmets övergripande mål är att stärka finansieringsmekanismer och planeringsprocesser för att möjliggöra implementering av klimatfinansiering av lokala myndigheter som förväntas att bidra till fattigdomsbekämpning och minskad utsatthet hos den fattigare delen av befolkningen. C:a 60% av budget avser bidrag till lokala myndigheter och bidrag direkt till utsatta hushåll för genomförandet av resilienshöjande åtgärder. Bidragsdelen uppskattas gynna 200 000 utsatt hushåll i 72 Union Parishad, i 7 Distrikt, som har bedömts vara mycket utsatta för klimatförändringar och ha en stor fattigdomsproblematik.
Division of Local Government (LGD) under Ministry of Local Government, Rural Development and Cooperatives kommer att ha det övergripande ansvaret för genomförandet av programmet enligt en etablerad samarbetsform mellan UNDP och Bangladsh regering. En styrgrupp för projektet kommer att tillsättas med deltagare från Ministry of Planning, Ministry of Disaster Management and Relief, finansministeriet, miljöministeriet, och andra berörda departement. Strygruppenkommer att ansvara för övergirpande syryning av programmet och godkänna projektplaner. UNDP och UNCDF kommer tillsammans hantera en Project Management Unit bestående av nationell och internationell personal för att stödja LGD i genomförandet av programmet under ledning av en National Project Director.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The project will address climate change impact in Bangladesh. The country is ranked 6th among the 10 countries of the world most affected by climate change and disasters and the country most at risk for sea level rise (with the exeption of small island states). It is experiencing change in rainfall, rise in temperature, and is often battered by extreme weather events like cyclones, floods and rise in sea level which compound into raised salinity of water resources and soil. A government estimate indicates that in five major disasters since 1998, the country suffered a loss of nearly 15% of GDP. These events exacerbate poverty and vulnerability of people on a regular basis.
The Government of Bangladesh already recognises the severity of climate change and therefore, the related concerns are being gradually mainstreamed in the national development policy planning and financing. The Government has formulated a national action plan (BCCSAP) that provides core programme direction. However, this sector is served by a number of sectoral policies which also shape the expenditure pattern in the national budget. While the local government institutions (LGIs) are mandated to implement many actions related to climate effects, these actions need to be included in the local plans as climate proofing initiatives.
The proposed programme will address gaps at local and national levels based on which the results have been designed. At the local level, despite being a repository of local knowledge and information, the LGIs fall short of harnessing the potentials from the local community. The mechanism for formulation of the Local Development Plans (LDP) has scope to engage the poor and vulnerable groups in a participatory way to reflect their climate-related needs and demands. Communities and households face difficulties in securing access to the planning and financing mechanism for sustainable development solutions. On the other hand, the Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) and local institutions who have long been functioning at local level for enhanced participation and accountability also shy off the process owing to lack of appropriate capacity. An in-depth analysis of the potentials and the gaps was carried out to identify the intervention areas at the local level.
The duration of the programme is 4 years, 2016-2020, with a total budget of US$ 20.0 million and a planned contribution of approximately USD 10 million (85 million SEK) by Sida and an already approved contribution of € 8 million by the EU. The project will enhance the capacity of vulnerable communities, local government institutions and civil society organisations for planning and financing climate change adaptation solutions in selected climate vulnerable areas. By achieving the objectives and results, the project will contribute to the reduction of poverty and vulnerability in Bangladesh.
This is expected to to result in: -Strengthened capacity of vulnerable people and local stakeholders for accountable planning and financing on Climate Change Adaptation/Disaster Risk Reduction actions for building resilience. -Enhanced access of LGIs and vulnerable households to climate funds have for climate resilient infrastructures and adaptive livelihoods. -Established evidence based advocacy for a mechanism for financing local resilience.
The programme is designed to benefit roughly 200,000 most vulnerable households in 72 unions in seven districts. The benefits are expected to come out of climate change adaptation actions at various levels, scaled up through local government institutions incorporating high quality accountability and participation of the most vulnerable people.
The Local Government Division (LGD) of the Ministry of Local Government Rural Development and Cooperatives will be the implementing agency and will assume overall responsibility for management and implementation of the project in a manner consistent with GoB and UNDP polices. A Project Steering Committee (PSC) will be formed with the participation of Ministry of Planning, Ministry of Disaster Management and Relief , Ministry of Finance, Ministry Environment and Forest, and other relevant ministries. The PSC will be responsible for consensus management decisions for the project when guidance is required, including approval of project plans and revisions. UNDP and UNCDF will jointly manage a Project Management Unit comprised of national and international staff members to support the LGD to implement the project, under the guidance of National Project Director.

Project Goal: Improved and inclusive local level planning and a strengthened financing mechanism for community-based climate change adaptation solutions through local governments. Output 1: Strengthened capacity of local governments, households and other local stakeholders to develop local plans that integrate climate change adaptation measures and disaster risk management. Output 2: Established financing mechanism to fund local governments and communities for implementing climate change adaptation measures. Output 3: Experience and evidence inform and contribute to further improvements in policies and practices for UPs and national systems in relation to climate change adaptation.

title.narrative: Local Governements Initiative on Climate Change
Local Governements Initiative on Climater Change

This helped brainstorm and identify their risks, which was prioritized at the planning exercise and incorporated in the long-term strategic plan of the Union Parishads (UPs). While UPs plan on building public goods for climate resilience (Risk Reduction Action Plan or RRAP), the community, on the other hand, plan for their own adaptive livelihood options (HHRRAP) for the same. Out of 72, targeted 71 UPs have received PBCRG grants (USD 1.79M) for implementing 228 climate change adaptation (CCA) schemes from their RRAP to create climate resilient public goods. There is potential for scaling up nature-based solutions with support from other sources such as philanthropists, development agencies, local community etc. to finance resilience and adaptation at the community level. On the other hand, 17,000 households of the community in 1,070 groups (based on interest, convenience, homogeneity choices, geographic proximity and communication) received USD 4.64M (2.88m disbursed in 2019, and 1.76m disbursed in 2018) and came up with 22 types of gender-responsive adaptive livelihood options. Adaptation actions at household level through CRF, who are most vulnerable and often left out from public goods benefits and widening the community scale adaptation micro-projects to reduce the vulnerability to climate change both followed the community risk assessment methodology. The vulnerable households and community within the Local Government (LG) constituencies interact in such a manner that ultimately ensure readiness to tackle climate hazards and strengthens the means for survival of the vulnerable community. However, such links require further strengthening and be informed from science-led predictions and scenarios of climate-induced risks. While, the project is well articulated in terms of participatory CRA, what will be more beneficial for climate change adaptation in this regard is a top-down method blended approach in promoting science-driven, informed participation of community in prioritizing their adaptation options at household and community levels. Potential for scaling-up of climate resilient/adaptive livelihoods: The core process of the selection of vulnerable households include (1) CRA and RRAP, (2) based on CRA, identification of two/three vulnerable wards from each UP, (3) conducting the census in these 147 wards, (4) identifying eligible beneficiaries (46,000) by minimum 0.5 vulnerability scores , (5) selection of relatively most vulnerable (26,000) households, with a primary shortlist (17000) and a waiting list (9000 HHs), (6) run a grievance register and redress mechanism and (7) finalize the 17000 HHs as final beneficiaries for the CRF. 98% of these HHs identified women member of the household as primary participant in the CRF and therefore, 16,660 are women as primary beneficiaries of CRF. These beneficiaries are pursuing 22 different types of climate resilient livelihoods in group enterprises, as a follow-up of the choices of the means of livelihoods and start-up grant support from the Project in two tranches. There are three (3) options to scale-up these livelihoods: (1) reaching to all eligible vulnerable groups (46,000 HHs) with different grants packages or reaching to all most vulnerable people (26,000 HHs) with common grant package; (2) scale-up of the most viable climate resilient livelihood options with formal credit market with higher environmental safeguard (i.e. crab fattening); and (3) facilitate private sector actors and co-design business case for scalable business opportunities on climate resilient means of livelihoods where vulnerable people secured income with backed-up skill training and social guarantee. A few examples include hydroponics, bio-flake, aquaponics, sunflower, crab-fattening, saline tolerant pulse, fruits and oil seeds production. Use of innovation for tracking and measuring adaptation: LoGIC demonstrates a comprehensive approach to ensure climate resilience. To keep records, track and measure adaptation, LoGIC has developed and put in place the state-of-the-art Accounting & Management Information Systems (MIS), Adaptation Tracking and Measuring (ATM) system for the project to make sure all the climate money are spent with rationale, the data are regularly entered and updated in the software which generates reports and tell stories of change in the field. Project’s M&E system inculcates all the information from the software and the database to create reports. Tapping upon innovation towards maximizing results, project has successfully trained 72 Union Parishads (LGI) Secretary on Accounting & MIS software. Field level project staffs have been provided hands-on training on filed-level data entry in changing context, future risks, use of grants etc. in the app-Tab-based ATM software. This approach has started to evolve as a transparent and accountable tool to measure climate change and adaptation data on the ground. Sustainable Development Goals: Progressing towards the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the Government of Bangladesh (GoB) has been pressing for more attention towards environmental issues. Of the 17 proposed SDGs, four (4) are related to climate change and environment and LoGIC contributes to or works towards Goals 1, 5, 10, 11, 13 and 16, i.e. contributing towards poverty eradiation, gender equality, sustainable communities, reduced inequalities, stronger institutions and climate change, broadly. LoGIC is working towards Goal 13.3, which is aimed to improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning through indicators (13.3.1 and 13.3.2). Likewise, with 13.2, i.e. to integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning. Although LoGIC has been working towards Goals 1, 5, 10, 11 and 16, only Goal 13 is included in the Strategic Results Framework. Specific achievements against goals are being studied and will be compiled for reporting. During the period, in early March 2020 a joint field visit was made to the project sites at Barguna district for five days. The joint mission was composed of EU, UNDP, UNCDF, GoB and Embassy of Sweden. Overall the findings were impressive. The third Project Steering Committee meeting took place virtually on 12 August 2020 chaired by the Senior Secretary, Local Government Division, Ministry of Local Government. Where relevant government ministry and departments participated. The meeting agreed and advocated for the top up and 2 years extension (up to 30 June 2023), expressed their commitment by agreeing to add 100 MBDT (about 1.2 MUSD) from GoB. Both EU and Embassy of Sweden participated in the meeting. Some major accomplishments 1. Community Risk Assessment (CRA) completed for 147 words in 72 Unions, 17,000 most vulnerable identified and listed in a through participatory manner. Among them 98% are female 2. Vulnerability identified for 147 words, 3. Climate resilient livelihood identified for 17,000 most vulnerable, transferred 1st tranche of Community Resilience Fund (CRF) through formal banking process. All these very remote area people have their bank account now with a formal bank. 4. Capacity enhancement activities done for all these 17,000 people 5. 243 climate resilient schemes implemented under the Performance Based Climate Resilient Grant (PBCRG) through Union Councils. Capacity enhancement of these Union parishad officials done 6. Information on Covid 19 disseminated to all the communities using different media and community well-being information collected from all the communities 7. 11 issues identified and ready for policy advocacy, so far 1 successful policy advocacy event completed with very good government buy inn.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Utvecklingsinsatsen utgörs av ett femårigt projekt inom området medieutveckling och mänskliga rättigheter vilket skall genomföras av Fojo Media Institute i samarbete med en lokal partner, Management and Resources Development Initiative (MRDI). Projektet har namnet Improving Investigative Journalism, Bangladesh. Verksamhet omfattar ett flertal komponenter som syftar till kapacitetsutveckling av medieorganisationer och individer verksamma inom media, nätverksbyggande, sektorstärkande och särskilda insatser på området säkerhet för medieaktörer.
Särskilt tematiskt fokus inom insatsen ligger på för Sida prioriterade frågor inom god samhällsstyrning, mänskliga rättigheter, arbetsrättsfrågor, jämställdhet och miljö och klimat.
Det är den Sidas bedömning att FOJO Media Institute har en unik ställning inom svenskt utvecklingssamarbete på området medieutveckling, har visat goda resultat i tidigare projekt av liknande natur i andra länder och har goda förutsättningar att nå uppställda resultat även i detta projekt i Bangladesh.
Insatsen i fråga är helt i linje med regeringens Strategi för Utvecklingssamarbetet med Bangladesh 2014-2020.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The development intervention consists of a five-year project in the field of media development and human rights, which will be implemented by the FOJO Media Institute in cooperation with a local partner, the Management and Resources Development Initiative (MRDI). The project is called Improving Investigative Journalism, Bangladesh. Operations comprise a number of components that aim at capacity development of media organizations and individuals active in the media, networking, sectoral strengthening and special efforts in the field of media security.
Special thematic focus within the initiative lies in Sida's priority issues in good governance, human rights, labor law, gender equality, environment and climate.
It is Sida's opinion that the FOJO Media Institute has a unique position in Swedish development cooperation in the field of media development, has shown good results in previous projects of similar nature in other countries and has good prospects for achieving results also in this project in Bangladesh.
The initiative in question is fully in line with the Government's Development Cooperation Strategy with Bangladesh 2014-2020.

The overarching development objective for the intervention is to: "Contribute to improving the conditions for people to raise themselves out of poverty, strengthening democracy, respect for human rights and gender equality, and to contribute to sustainable development." The specific objective of the intervention is stated as “Media in Bangladesh contributes to strengthened democracy and gender equality, greater respect for human rights and freedom from oppression.”To this Objective, Fojo links three outcomes – two immediate and one intermediate. 1) The first immediate outcome is linked to the strengthening of individual media outlets and journalists in their production of qualitative journalism: "Targeted media houses and news providers identify, research and produce high quality investigative journalism, particularly on gender equality, labour rights, corruption and environmental impact and climate change". 2) The second immediate outcome is focused on strengthening the media sector as a whole, to enable a conducive environment for this production: "Targeted partners in the media sector collaborate to create a conducive environment for investigative journalism, particularly on gender equality, labour rights, corruption and environmental impact and climate change". The theory of change links the outcomes to the overarching and the specific objective through the following logic: "The stories published result in an invigorated debate on issues related to gender equality, labour rights, corruption and environmental impact and climate change as well as other issues vital for the development of democracy, gender equality and respect for human rights. The debate contributes to strengthened democracy and gender equality, greater respect for human rights and freedom from oppression. Strengthened democracy and gender equality, greater respect for human rights and freedom from oppression contributes to improving the conditions for people to raise themselves out of poverty in a better environment.”

participating-org.narrative: University, college or other teaching institution, research institute or think-tank

sector.narrative: Media and free flow of information

tag.narrative: 13.3 - Förbättra utbildningen, medvetenheten och den mänskliga och institutionella kapaciteten vad gäller begränsning av klimatförändringarna, klimatanpassning, begränsning av klimatförändringarnas konsekvenser samt tidig varning.
13.3 - Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.

17.9 - Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the Sustainable Development Goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.

17.9 - Öka det internationella stödet för genomförande av effektiv och riktad kapacitetsuppbyggnad i utvecklingsländerna till stöd för nationella planer för att genomföra alla målen för hållbar utveckling, inklusive genom samarbete nord–syd och syd–syd samt trepartssamarbete.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Den 16 maj 2017 inkom Kambodjas jämställdhetsministerium, Ministry of Women (MoWA), och UNDP med en gemensam ansökan om finansiering av ett jämställdhetsprogram med titel "Leading the Way Forward". Det föreslagna programmet var en fortsättning på det tidigare stödet till MoWA och UNDP (avtalspart UNDP) och det gemensamma programmet "Partnership for Gender Equality (PGE) III" (insatsnummer 51100037), till vilket Sida gett ett stöd om 8 000 000 SEK under perioden 2012-2015.
I samband med insatsens beredning under våren 2017, var avsikten att stödet skulle kanaliseras till både MoWa och UNDP med två avtalspartners. UNDP skulle hantera 50 % av stödet genom en s.k. National Implementation Modality (NIM), genom vilken MoWA skulle ansvara för genomförande under uppföljning av UNDP, och en gradvis ökning av direktfinansiering skulle ske till MoWA. I januari 2017 gav Sida stöd till MoWA i form av en teknisk expertis, vars syfte var att bistå parterna att utveckla former för det nya programmet. Ambassaden höll ett kommittémöte om insatsen den 1 juli 2017. En reviderad version av ansökan inkom ambassaden den 26 juli 2017.
I samband med det förvärrade politiska läget under hösten 2017, med Kambodjas beslut om upplösning av oppositionspartiet, har formerna för samarbetet ändrats. Sida har kommit fram till följande hållning i förhållande till statliga partners:
"Till dess att den svenska regeringen eventuellt väljer att ge Sida andra instruktioner, ingås inga nya insatsavtal inom utvecklingssamarbetet som innebär att det kanaliseras finansiella resurser direkt till staten, med undantag för stöd till utbildning och forskning."
Finansiellt stöd till, och avtal med, jämställdhetsministeriet är därmed inte längre aktuellt. Insatsen bedöms dock fortsatt vara relevant. Den 11 december 2017 inkom UNDP med projektförslaget "Project to Support the Leading the Way for Gender Equality Programme". Insatsen syftar till att stärka MoWA:s program: att stärka den offentliga sektorn genom att utforma och genomföra jämställdhetspolicys, stärka samverkan kring jämställdhet, främja en attitydförändring för ökad jämställdhet hos allmänheten och unga kambodjaner, samt främja ökat antal kvinnor i beslutsfattande positioner liksom ett stärkt kvinnligt ledarskap. I tillägg har stöd till civilsamhället och dess roll inom jämställdhetsarbetet inkluderats. Avtalspartner är UNDP.
Genom NIM-finansiering, ansvarar jämställdhetsministeriet för medelshantering och genomför insatser. I tillägg finansieras insats för särskilt utsatta grupper genomförs i samverkan med utbildnings-, civil service- och informationsministerierna. Genom programmet erhåller jämställdhetsministeriet kapacitetsstöd för att genomföra jämställdhetsinsatser.
Insatsen kommer att pågå under perioden 1 september 2017 till 31 december 2020 och uppgår till totalt ca 17,5 MSEK (2 048 629 USD), utav vilket Sida finansierar 9,5 MSEK. Resterande belopp finansieras av UNDP i form av en internationell teknisk rådgivare samt finansiering av enstaka insatser.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The programme aims to support Cambodia in effectively institutionalizing gender equality policies across government, strengthen coordination on gender equality, promote changes in attitude in favor of enhanced equality amongst citizens and young Cambodians, and promote an increased number of women in decision making positions and a strengthened feminist leadership. Besides support to the implementation of activities, MoWA will, through UNDP, receive support to strengthen its capacity to plan for, implement and follow up on gender equality interventions.

The overall goal of the programme is to contribute to "Enabled environment for gender equality, women’s empowerment and feminist leaderships in Cambodia". The goal will be achieved through the following three outcomes: 1) More effective integration of gender policies across government, and more effective performance of Gender Machinery to lead gender equality mainstreaming with inclusion of disadvantaged groups of women and girls. 2) Public behavioural change in favour of gender equality is promoted among young Cambodians. 3) Increased number of and capacities of women in decision-making positions and strengthened feminist leadership.

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

tag.narrative: 5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Insatsen School Improvement Fund (SIF) är en givar- och myndighetsgemensam fond för förvaltningsmedel till skolor i Kambodja. Medel från fonden distribueras till alla offentliga skolor från förskola till och med sekundärskolan. Denna fond ersätter den tidigare svenskfinansierade fonden School Improvement Grants (SIG) och den statliga School Operational Budget (SOB).
Det kambodjanska finansministeriet, Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF), är Sidas avtalspartner som representant för den kambodjanska regeringen och mottagare av det svenska bidraget. De svenska medlen överförs från MEF (från ett specifikt bankkonto för Sidas bidrag) till det kambodjanska utbildningsministeriet, Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports (MoEYS). Förmedling till skolorna av SIF-programmets medel sker genom banktransfereringar från MoEYS. Avtalet klargör att MoEYS är ansvarigt ministerium för genomförande av programmet och Sidas huvudsakliga motpart i genomförandet.
Framsteg har skett inom utbildningssektorn i Kambodja under det senaste årtiondet, särskilt på låg- och mellanstadienivå. Ett antal system- och ledningsrelaterade svagheter kvarstår dock. Vidare är utbildningskvaliteten låg och alltför få barn fullföljer skolan bortom de första sju skolåren. För att bistå i att hantera några av dessa utmaningar beslutade Sida i september 2013 att lämna stöd till en utbyggnad av ett system för flexibla skolbidrag genom SIG-programmet.
En uttalad ambition för insatsen var att de lärdomar som genererades inom SIG-programmet skulle påverka det existerande statliga transfereringssystemet för förvaltningsbidrag till skolorna (SOB) genom att SIG och SOB skulle slås samman inom ramen för ett enhetligt, effektivt och flexibelt system för överföring och hantering av delegerade skolbidrag. Avsikten med Sidas stöd till SIG var således också att uppnå en systemeffekt. För att minska riskerna med en omfattande kontanthantering i flera led inom utbildningssystemet, ställde Sida som krav att bankkonton skulle öppnas för skolorna för att möjliggöra direkttransfereringar från central nivå till de enskilda skolorna. Hantering av formella finansiella flöden sker nu via banksystemet för alla offentliga skolor.
Enligt den studie av offentliga finansiella flöden inom utbildningsystemet (Public Expenditure Tracking Survey – PETS) som har genomförts av Världsbanken under 2017 har användningen av banktransfereringar i sig lett till en stor förändring för att minska felaktig användning av medel. Den PETS som genomfördes av Världsbanken 2006 fann att endast 70 % av förvaltningsbidragen kom fram till skolorna, PETS 2017 finner att 100 % av medlen nu kommer fram. PETS 2017, liksom andra rapporter, konstaterar vidare att den kvalitetshöjning som skett på lokal skolnivå kan härledas direkt från SIG systemet på grund av dess fokus på lokala behov och förutsättningar.
Det nya systemet för förvaltningsbidrag till skolor, SIF, bygger på erfarenhet från såväl SOB som SIG. Den största skillnaden mot SIG-programmet är att Kambodja och Sverige åtar sig att gemensamt finansiera insatsen. SIG-programmet var inledningsvis endast finansierat av Sverige men på grund av växelkursförändringar och svenska kronans sjunkande värde under genomförandetiden bidrog det kambodjanska finansministeriet med medel motsvarande underskottet i den planerade budgeten. Regler och instruktioner för de lokala skolornas användning och rapportering av medlen i SIF programmet är i stort sett samstämmiga med reglerna och instruktionerna för SIG-programmet.
Genom SIF kommer bidrag att nå ut till samtliga ca 8 900 offentliga skolor från grundskola till gymnasium (fler än 11 000 enheter, när de förskolor som finns inom vissa primärskolor räknas in). SIF:s förvaltningsbidrag, i motsats till det tidigare SOB systemet, innebär att skolorna har långtgående befogenheter att bestämma över hur delegerade medel ska användas. Användningen av SIF-medlen regleras i en instruktion fastställd av MoEYS; i huvudsak får medlen användas för ökad undervisningskvalitéet, mindre underhåll av lokaler samt stöd till svaga elever. Härigenom ökar möjligheterna att tillfredsställa de faktiska behov som finns i skolorna, vilket i sin tur på sikt förväntas bidra till förbättrad utbildningskvalitet och minskade avhopp.
På grund av den negativa politiska utvecklingen i Kambodja under 2017 har Sida beslutat att tills vidare inte ingå nya insatsavtal inom utvecklingssamarbetet som innebär att det kanaliseras finansiella resurser direkt till staten, med undantag för stöd till utbildning och forskning. Fortsatt stöd till decentraliseringsreformen kommer därmed inte att utgå. Ökad kunskap och höjd utbildningsnivå bedöms långsiktigt vara förutsättning för ett hållbart demokratiskt samhälle i Kambodja. De senaste decenniernas stora framsteg för ökad tillgång till grundutbildning och en långsam kvalitetshöjning inom utbildningsystemet, samt den kraftiga ökningen av antalet studerande på högskolenivå bedöms ha bidragit till den snabba ekonomiska utvecklingen som landet åtnjuter och de ökade kraven som framställs på medborgarinflytande och yttrandefrihet. Fortsatt och långsiktigt stöd till utbildning och forskning bedöms vara ett viktigt bidrag till en långsiktig demokratisk utveckling.
Mot bakgrund av ovanstående föreslås att Sida lämnar stöd till insatsen School Improvement Fund för åren 2018-2021, med ett totalbelopp om 186 500 000 kronor. Av medlen kommer Sida att behålla 6 500 000 kronor för uppföljningskomponenten medan resterande 180 000 000 kronor utbetalas direkt till det kambodjanska finansministeriet (MEF).

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The intervention School Improvement Fund is jointly funded by external development partners and the Government of Cambodia and provides operational funding to all public schools in Cambodia from pre-school to upper-secondary level. This fund replaces the Swedish funded School Improvement Grants (SIG) as well as the Government budget item School Operational Budget (SOB)

The objective of the programme is to support MoEYS in establishing a sustainable School Improvement Fund (SIF) that will support improved completion and graduation rates of students in early childhood education, primary, lower secondary and upper secondary levels, with enhanced gender parity at all levels. In order to achieve this objective SIDA will support the co-financing of the SIF between 2018 and 2021. This co-financing will incrementally decrease each year in order to assist Royal Government of Cambodia in incrementally graduating towards full financing of the SIF by 2022. In addition, SIDA will provide complementary funding to assist the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports (MoEYS) in conducting evidence-based impact monitoring, technical reviews and programme evaluation. Broader capacity building support to the establishment of the new SIF will be provided through the MoEYS Capacity Development Partnership Fund (CDPF). The expected outcome objectives of the interevention are: (1) expanded access to education services at pre-school, primary and secondary levels; (2) improved completion rates for primary, lower and upper secondary levels; and (3) improved capacity for school management.

participating-org.narrative: Ministry of Economy and Finance, Phnom Pehn

tag.narrative: 4.1 - By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
4.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla flickor och pojkar fullbordar avgiftsfri och likvärdig grundskole- och gymnasieutbildning av god kvalitet som leder till relevanta och ändamålsenliga kunskaper.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) has changed the name of SIF to School Operational Fund (SOB) although the agreement on Swedish support continues to use the SIF. The second year of the Sida support to the SOF/SIF had a better start than the first year as all the Swedish funds were disbursed to the schools as planned early in the year, in late January or early February. The first tranche of the two annual disbursements of the Government funds was disbursed together with the Swedish funds. The merge of the two parallel funding structures, the external development partner funding (in this case mainly Swedish funds) and the funds coming from the Government’s budget into a single funding stream was not fully however implemented but is expected to be fully implemented from 2020. The gradual decrease of the Swedish funding and the corresponding increased of Government funding has taken place as planned. During different field visits conducted by Embassy staff to schools around the country, teachers, principals and members of the School Support Committees expressed that they had received funds more or less on time and the full amount. The use of the banking system for transfers of funds to schools that was introduced with the SIG (the earlier Swedish funded support to schools) has had a huge effect on increased transparency and accountability over fund flows and the use of funds at school level. That informal “leaks” of funds from the central funding instances to the local level have stopped has had an strong anti-corruption effect. This impression is also supported by findings reported in different reports on other aspects of education development by different organisations such as NEP, World Bank, ADB, UNICEF and UNESCO. The reports from the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports (MoEYS) show that the absolute biggest part of the funds have been utilised to buy additional learning material, paper, pens, simple laboratory equipment and also books for the school libraries. Around 70 % of the SIF funds were used for this purpose. The second largest part, 15 %, was for providing extra lessons to slow learners, approximately 10 % were used for minor reparations and ca. 5 % for administrative purposes. The reporting from MoEYS is based on an aggregated reporting line, from schools to districts, from districts to province, and from province to the central level. It is therefore difficult to analyse if there are any major differences between different district or schools. At province level there does not seem to be any significant difference on the use of the funds. The progress in relation to the expected outcomes in the framework has mainly been somewhat positive with a few setbacks. At primary level the completion rate reached 88.2 % which is higher that the target rate of 82.1 %. However, the indicators on admission, dropout and repetitions did not meet the target. The explanations given by MoEYS is a) that schools have improved student assessments by conducting stricter summative tests of students leading to a higher percentage of failure on test, leading to drop-out and especially increased repetitions; b) schools still have limited resources available, including financial and personnel to support students at risk. The drop-out rate in lower secondary education in the academic year 2018-2019 increased by 2.8 % from previous academic year, from 15.8 % to 18.6 %. Particularly boys tend to drop-out at this level. MoEYS describes the reason to this is: “The perennial economic problem of families especially in the rural areas, which prompted teenage students to seek jobs to be able to help the financial needs of the family, is always a factor affecting the drop-out rate.” UNICEF, CDPF and others have conducted research on the issue and the poverty is seen as the major factor behind the drop-out. Addressing this is however to a large degree outside of the what can be addressed within the education system. One of the options is increased scholarships, around 100 000 poor students received Government scholarships in the academic year 2018-2019.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Water Services Trust Fund - Landsbygdsvatten, sanitet & vattenresursförvaltning
COVID-19 Water Services Trust Fund - Rural Water, Sanitation & Water Resources Management

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Programmet, som är samfinansierat av Sverige och Finland, syftar ytterst till att gagna marginaliserade kvinnor och män på landsbygden i Kenya genom ökad och rättvis tillgång till vatten och sanitet, exempelvis genom konstruktion av nya borrhål, rehabilitering av icke-fungerande pumpar, och sanitetslösningar i skolor - och förbättrad förvaltning av vattenresurser - exempelvis genom konstruktion av sanddammar för vattenlagring och stärkt efterlevnad av lagstiftning. Mot bakgrund av den förändrade kenyanska kontexten med decentraliserat ansvar för att leverera vatten- och sanitetstjänster är det nödvändigt för samarbetpartnern Water Services Trust Fund (WSTF) att arbeta utifrån en ny ansats som bygger på samarbete med och stöd till nya aktörer på länsregeringsnivå (county) för att nå målet. Dessutom är det i syfte att dra lärdom av tidigare WSTF vattenprojekt på landsbygden i Kenya nödvändigt att revidera projektcyklerna för vatten och sanitet (CPC - community project cycle) och för vattenresurshantering (WDC - water resources users associations development cycle) vilka utgör två av Water Services Trust Funds huvudsakliga arbetsmetoder på lokal nivå. Viktiga skillnader i jämförelse med tidigare struktur är: utgångspunkten är länsnivå, samarbetet koncentrerat till sex län, projekten väljs utifrån lokala behov och planering på länsnivå, kluster av projekt, ett vattenbolag som genomförande part per län, förvaltning av vattenresurser länkas närmare till vattenförsörjningsprojekt, kontrollen av vidareförmedling av medel stärks, kapacitetsutveckling bygger på bedömningar av samarbetspartners kapacitet samt modeller för hållbar drift kommer att utforskas, inklusive public-private partnerships. Förändringarna är främst avsedda att leda till ökad effektivitet, hållbarhet, fattigdomsfokus och bättre kontroll på vidareförmedlade medel. Fattigdomskopplingen avses att stärkas och institutionaliseras genom att länsregeringarna ökar sin kompetens och kapacitet för 'pro-poor' planering och budgetering inom vatten- och sanitetsområdet. WSTF's interna kapacitet och effektivitet kommer också stärkas som en del av insatsen. Programmet innebär en avsevärd förändring av WSTFs arbetssätt och förväntas leda till att WSTF kan utvidga programmet till andra län. Det är viktigt att framhålla att programmet innehåller många osäkerhetsfaktorer eftersom flera viktiga aspekter fortfarande inte är färdigställda såsom resultatramverk. Det första året blir därmed avgörande för att få samtliga system på plats och "milestones" har överenskommits för att ge vägledning i arbetet och tydliggöra vilka aktiviteter som måste ha avslutats efter det första året. Utöver avtalsvillkor har en rad andra åtgärder vidtagits för att säkerställa att det första året bygger en solid bas för det fortsatta programmet, exempelvis att programmet innehåller en betydande TA komponent och Sverige kommer kontraktera en oberoende monitoring konsult. Dessa åtgärder sammantagna väntas leda till att programmet kan leverera förväntade resultat. (Konsulten utgör en separat insats med separat beslut då Trac-systemet inte tillåter komponenter.)

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The programme, supported jointly by Sweden and Finland, is ultimately intended to benefit the marginalized women and men in rural Kenya through improved and equitable access to water and sanitation - e.g. by means of constructing new boreholes, rehabilitation of non-functional pumps, and constructing sanitation facilities in schools - and improved water resources management - e.g. by means of constructing sand dams for water storage or strengthened enforcement of regulations. In light of the changing Kenyan context of devolved responsibility for delivering water and sanitation services, to achieve this goal it is necessary for Water Services Trust Fund (WSTF) to adopt a new approach based on cooperation with and support to new partners at the county level. Moreover, in order to draw lessons from previous WSTF rural water projects there is need to revise the project cycles for water and sanitation (CPC) and for water resource management (WDC), which constitute the two main work methods of WSTF work at the local level. The key differences compared with previous set-up are: county-level as point of departure, projects concentrated to six counties, partnership with the county governments, projects are based on local needs and planning at the county level, clusters of projects, water companies as implementing partners in each county, the management of water resources is more closely linked to water supply projects, the control of the forwarding of funds is strengthened, capacity development is based on assessments of partners' capacities and sustainable management models will be explored, including public-private partnerships. The changes are designed to increase efficiency, sustainability, poverty focus and the control of the forwarded funds. The poverty focus will be strengthened and institutionalized through the county governments increasing their skills and capabilities for 'pro-poor' planning and budgeting in water and sanitation. WSTF's internal capacity and efficiency will also be strengthened as part of the intervention. The programme involves a considerable change of WSTFs working methods and it is envisaged that WSTF will be able to extend the programme to other counties. It is important to emphasize that the programme contains many uncertainties given that several important cornerstones of the programme are not yet completed, such as, the results framework.The first year will thus be crucial to ensure that all the systems and structures are in place and milestones have been agreed to provide guidance on this process and clarify what activities must be completed by the end of the first year. In addition to the agreement conditions, a number of measures, such as Sweden contracting an independent monitoring consultant and a strong TA component being incorporated into the programme, have therefore been taken to ensure that the first-year operations will build a solid basis for the programme. Such measures are foreseen to ensure that the programme delivers the expected results. (The consultant will entail a separate contribution and decision given that the Trac-system does not allow for components.)

sector.narrative: Basic drinking water supply and basic sanitation

tag.narrative: 6.1 - By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.
6.1 - Senast 2030 uppnå allmän och rättvis tillgång till säkert och ekonomiskt överkomligt dricksvatten för alla.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.
6.5 - By 2030, implement integrated water resources management at all levels, including through transboundary cooperation as appropriate.
6.5 - Senast 2030 genomföra en integrerad förvaltning av vattenresurser på alla nivåer, när så är lämpligt genom gränsöverskridande samarbete.
6.b - Stödja och stärka lokalsamhällenas deltagande i arbetet med att förbättra vatten- och sanitetshanteringen.
6.b - Support and strengthen the participation of local communities in improving water and sanitation management.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Results as at 30 June 2017 Outcome 1: Enhanced county capacity: - Water Utility Mapping was carried out for 5 counties with a view to supporting the Water Utilities to analyse water Points, coverage and schemes in their service areas for future planning. - Capacity building of the Water Utilities (implementing partners of the actual projects) on procurement, financial management, etc. Such training was done by the County Resident Monitors and/or the contracted Service Agents. - There were also county exchange visits carried out for peer learning purposes. - A number of activities under this outcome were pushed to 2017/18, like the development of a reporting framework for the counties, development of holistic county water master plans and strategies. Outcome 2: Improved Management of Water Resources: - The continued implementation of 10 Water Resources Users Associations (WRUAs) projects (started late 2015/2016) were supported to undertake catchment protection activities such as erosion control through gabions, pegging of riparian land and tree planting. - To deliver on the target of supporting WRUAs to become sustainable, an analysis was carried out of WRUA management support in business planning. - The WRUAs operating across more than one county – so called ‘transboundary WRUAs’ could not be primarily not be funded as there was no MoU with the up-stream or downstream counties. E.g. in one case the investment had to be made for a water source which was located in an adjacent county to the J6P-county. Therefore work was undertaken to reach an agreement between the bordering counties and a strategy and a mechanism for funding the transboundary WRUAs was developed. This approach and strategy with MoUs between the bordering counties is foreseen to become a model for addressing transboundary WRM issues across Kenya. Outcome 3: Water Supply - 31 water supply projects were approved for funding during the period and subsequent procurement and implementation were supported. In many cases the projects were extensions of already existing schemes, additional distributions lines, tanks, etc., to increase access and number of connections or they involved metering to improve the collection of revenue as well as making more water available for customers downstream. 3 projects in Narok were discontinued, i.e., the WSTF did not fund these investments as they had not received a noobjection on the procurement process from WSTF before awarding contracts and initiating the works. - At the close of the reporting period no projects had been finalized. This delay is of concern as it has taken more than 1 year to have the projects completed. Some factors driving this delay are low capacity of the water utilities in procurement, workmanship has been poor in some instances, requiring corrections and adjustments, WSTF has not always been responsive to no-objections, etc. - Capacity development support to the water utilities in service delivery models for the water supply Projects has not yet started. - Rural Water Utilities Technical Package/Tool Kit and Brochures in support of the water utilities were produced. Outcome 4: Sanitation - This outcome area is also delayed and 22 projects on institutional sanitation were awaiting finalization as the reporting period ended. Procurement and implementation for the same projects were supported during the reporting period. There have been challenges in spreading the investments too thinly, constructing only one sanitation block per school instead of focusing on fewer schools and meeting all their needs. - Community-led total sanitation: training on CLTS triggering for the public health officers and CRMs was carried out in all counties and the GESI guidelines were used to target the poorest communities for CLTS. Here the challenges has in part been that the funds for sanitation is channeled through the Water Utilities - WSTF developed GESI-responsive designs for institutional sanitation that were circulate to Water Utilities and are in use during construction. Outcome 5: WSTF capacity strengthened - Additional tools were developed, such as the 'Design-Cost Protocols' to support the designs of the water supply and sanitation projects. - Annual operations monitoring of the urban, rural and results-based investments was carried out to follow up on projects’ functionality and sustainability and take appropriate actions. - The County Resident Monitors (CRMs) were supported by trainings, payments and logistical issues. - The Kenya Water Week was held back to back with the Annual Water Sector Review in November 2016 attracting many different stakeholders and providing an important platform for sharing knowledge and experiences. The county level was well-represented. Furthermore, Water Innovation awards were given out to entrepreneurs.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 PPDP Kenya Market Led Dairy Supply Chain Programme
COVID-19 PPDP Kenya Market Led Dairy Supply Chain Programme

description.narrative: New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 This is a Public Private Development Partnership which is the result of collaboration between the Kenyan Dairy Processor NKCC, TetraLaval, Producer Organizations, Heifer International and Sida. The intervention's overarching objective is to contribute to an inclusive economic growth and reduce poverty in Kenya by developing a dairy supply chain that benefits smallholder dairy farmers in 5 counties in Kenya. The intervention builds the capacity of smallholder dairy farmers to significantly increase production and links them to a formal stable market. Consequently, the intervention objectives are to increase productivity, increase milk collection, improve milk quality, increase farmer incomes, increase the involvement of women and youth in milk production and last but not least increase the use of environmentally friendly dairy production practices. This is expected to improve incomes for 30 000 poor dairy smallholder farmers whereby 15000 are women.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen är en Public Private utvecklingspartnerskap och bygger på ett samarbete mellan det Kenyanska mejeriproduktföretaget NKCC, det svenska livsmedels och förpackningsföretaget TetraLaval, Lokala Mejeriorganisationer, Heifer och Sida. Det övergripande syftet är att bidra till fattigdomsminsking och inklusiv ekonomisk tillväxt i fem län i västra och östra Kenya genom att förbättra mejerivärdekedjan som domineras av fattiga och sårbara bönder. De fem länen som insatsen genomförs i är Nandi, Trans-Nzoia, Uasin Gishu, Elgeyo Marakwet i västra Kenya och Tharaka Nithi i östra Kenya. Insatsen strävar efter att bygga upp de små mejeriböndernas kapacitet samt länka dem till en stabil och formell marknad. Detta i sin tur förväntas leda till förbättrad inkomst för 30 000 fattiga mejeribönder varav 15000 är kvinnor.

The intervention targets 30,000 smallholder dairy farmers of which 15000 are women in five counties in Kenya to significantly improve their production as well as their linkages to a market led dairy value chain. The programme is intended to Increase milk productivity between 50-100% from current levels; Increase milk collection volumes in milk collection centres and bulking centres to at least 125,000 litres per day; Improve milk quality; Increase the incomes of at least 70% of participating farmers and households to at least USD 3,285 per annum or USD 9 per day by the end of the project period; Ensure gainful participation of at least 15,000, or 50%, women in dairy value chain and Producer Organizations to increase employment and incomes and; Increase the use and adoption of environmental friendly dairy production practices amongst the target group.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

2.3 - By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.

2.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla jordbrukets produktivitet och inkomster för småskaliga livsmedelsproducenter, i synnerhet kvinnor, ursprungsfolk, familjejordbrukare, boskapsskötande nomader samt fiskare, inklusive genom säker och lika tillgång till mark, andra produktionsresurser och insatsvaror, kunskap, finansiella tjänster och marknader samt möjligheter till värdeskapande och sysselsättning utanför jordbruket.

2.4 - By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

2.4 - Senast 2030 uppnå hållbara system för livsmedelsproduktion samt införa motståndskraftiga jordbruksmetoder som ökar produktiviteten och produktionen, som bidrar till att upprätthålla ekosystemen, som stärker förmågan till anpassning till klimatförändringar, extrema väderförhållanden, torka, översvämning och andra katastrofer och som successivt förbättrar mark- och jordkvaliteten.
5.b - Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
5.b - Öka användningen av gynnsam teknik, i synnerhet informations- och kommunikationsteknik, för att främja kvinnors egenmakt
8.2 - Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value added and labour-intensive sectors.
8.2 - Uppnå högre ekonomisk produktivitet genom diversifiering, teknisk uppgradering och innovation, bland annat genom att fokusera på sektorer med högt förädlingsvärde och hög arbetsintensitet.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
