title.narrative: Agreement 51110075 PPDP Dairy Chain Development in Kenya 2017-2021
Decision PPDP Dairy chain development Kenya 2017 - 2021
PPDP Kenya Market Led Dairy Supply Chain Program-Grant Agreement
Agreement Amendment - PPDP Supply chain development in Kenya
PPDP Kenya Market Led Dairy Supply Chain Program-Decision (51110075)

description.narrative: Key among the activities targeted to achieve the above objectives were farmer mobilizations, establishment of management systems at county and producer organizations (POs) level as well as establishment of sustainable extensions systems. Building the capacitites of POs, farmers and the extension service providers was a priority, with all the mobilised 17,517 farmers being trained through the established extension structures. POs mobilisation and sentization entailed introducing Dairy Farm assistants (DFAs) to officers of county governments, Agricultural Sector Support Program (ASDSP) and POs. Farmers were sentised on the project based on the milk routes per the 24 POs and a total of 656 farmers (457 male and 199 Female) were reached. 26th February 2019- field visit to Embu attended by all the partners in the project was a display of close collaboration between the POs, NKCC and great coordination with the ASDSP existing structures. It also unearthed some of the challenges with regard to milk purchase price/payment by NKCC to the POs and the joint deliberation instruments put in place to solve these issues was impressive. Talks to revert ownership of NKCC or allow gradual ownership by farmers into NKCC to enable them recoup their investments and earn better incomes and profits were at the onset and this has been reinforced by the Governments drastic steps to reorganise, restructure and revamp NKCC factories around the country. The farmers we met during the field visit who are organised under dairy management groups also called dairy interest groups who form the local cooperatives, cited increase in their milk collection and membership respectively, since they started their partnership with KEMDAP. The team was impressed with their work. They have plans to invest more in the business and the project will link them to Impact Ventures to seek for funds. They would like to establish a feed milling plant, expand their milk processing and also venture in milk transportation business through involvement of the youth. Availability of quality feeds throughout the year for consistent milk production was still noted as a challenge
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Kenyas regering (GoK) har bett Sverige att bidra till genomförandet av landets s.k. Vision 2030, den nya jordbrukspolicyn samt s.k. Agricultural Sector Development Strategy (ASDS 2010 – 2020) genom fortsatt finansiering till jordbrukssektorn via ASDSP programmet (Agricultural Sector Development Support Programme, fas II) under aktivitetsperioden 2017-2022 och räkenskapsåret juli 2017 till juni 2022. Kenyas egen finansiering till programmet uppgår till 2 092 500 000 KES, varav KES 1 292 500 000 kommer från landets 47 regionstyrelser och KES 800 000 000 från landets regering. Sverige har tillfrågats om att stödja programmet genom att tillhandahålla ekonomisk och teknisk hjälp motsvarande SEK 352 126 500, vilket även inkluderar EU-delegerade bidrag på SEK 52 126 500. EU-delegering baseras på positiva erfarenheter från samarbetet mellan EU, Sverige och Tyskland under fas 1 av programmet mellan 2014 och 2016. EU-överenskommelsen har gjorts i enlighet med det s.k. Action Document som gäller "stöd till jordbrukssektorns transformeringsprocess samt en decentraliserad markförvaltning". Detta godkändes av Europakommissionen 2015 (KE/FED/037-776) och finansierades genom EU-Kenya Cooperation 11th European Development Fund National Indicative Programme för perioden 2014-2020. Grunden till avtalet mellan Sverige och EU var handlingsplanen "transformation av jordbrukssektorn i Kenya", som utformades i december 2016. Planen syftar till att utveckla strukturer och kapaciteten för en bredare sektoröverskridande rådgivning och koordination på nationell, mellanstatlig och regional nivå i syfte att stärka de policies och institutioner som påverkar värdekedjornas utveckling. Resultaten för EU-delegeringen är primärt sammankopplade med ASDSP II Outcome 4. EU-bidragen är emellertid inte öronmärkta utan kommer att följas upp och rapporteras tillsammans med övriga medel.
Det föreslagna programmet är en fortsättning (fas II) av ett liknande program (ASDSP I) som avslutades i juni 2017 och som stötts och samfinansierats av Sida och Kenyas regering (huvudsakligen genom landets regering) under perioden 2012 – 2017. Enligt den interna slututvärderingen har programmet uppnått goda resultat, bland annat följande: etablerande av strukturer och institutioner som behövs för utvecklingen av tre prioriterade värdekedjor per region; introduktion och stärkande av kapacitet för att kunna utveckla värdekedjor på nya sätt där den privata sektorn och andra intressenter (huvudsakligen den privata sektorn) involveras, det har även genomförts andra värdekedjeinitiativ; man har nått ut till 563.347 värdekejdeaktörer (46 % manliga, 36 % kvinnliga och 18 % ungdomar); ökade inkomster (78 % för manliga företagare eller hushåll, 25 % för kvinnliga hushåll och 15 % för ungdomshushåll); ökad livsmedelssäkerhet från 61 %, 58 % respektive 61 % från utgångsläget 32,8 %, 38 % respektive 42 % under 2016 för manliga, kvinnliga respektive ungdomshushåll; ökad produktivitet i prioriterade värdekedjor som mejerinäring och bananodling. Utvärderingen påvisar även värdet av utvecklingsaktörer och regering att fungera som facilitatorer.
Syftet med ASDSP II är att stödja omställningen av jordbruks-, boskaps- och fiskeproduktion till kommersiellt orienterade företag för säkerställande av en hållbar livsmedels- och matförsörjning. Syftet är att utveckla prioriterade värdekedjor (VC) för sysselsättning, ökade inkomster och och förbättrad livsmedels- och matförsörjningen. Detta ska ske genom att man sammanför de olika värdekedjeaktörerna (VCA) så att utvecklingshinder kan överbryggas och värdekedjorna utvecklas på ett rättvist och hållbart sätt. ASDSP II är förankrat genom den nya jordbrukspolitiken (Agriculture Policy, AP) och bygger på resultaten från ASDSP I samt det man lärt från andra program inom denna sektor. Insatsen riktar sig till alla VCA:er, från primära producenter till konsumenter genom stöd till aktiviteter fokuserade på de fyra största utvecklingshindren: 1. Låg produktivitet längs med hela värdekedjan; 2. Otillräckliga entreprenörskunskaper bland aktörer i hela värdekedjan inklusive tjänsteleverantörer; 3. Dålig marknadstillgång för värdekedjeaktörerna; och 4. Svaga och inadekvata strukturer och kapacitet för rådgivning och koordination inom sektorn.
Insatsen förväntas bidra till till fyra övergripande resultat: 1) Ökad produktivitet för prioriterade värdekedjor; 2) Stärkt entreprenörskap hos värdekedjeaktörer (VCA); 3) Förbättrad marknadstillgång för prioriterade värdekejdeaktörer; och 4. Stärkta strukturer och kapacitet för rådgivning och samarbete inom sektorn, speciellt inom den decentraliserade strukturen. Insatsen bedöms vara en förutsättning för landsbygdens strukturomvandling eftersom den förväntas bidra till en kommersialisering av det småskaliga jordbruket.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The overall goal of ASDSP II is "to support transformation of crop, livestock and fisheries production into commercially oriented Enterprises that ensure sustainable food and nutrition security. The programme has a purpose "to develop sustainable priority value chains for improved income, employment, food and nutrition security". To attain this purpose, the programme will aim to address three main problems: Low value chain productivity; inadequate entrepreneurial skills of value chain actors; low access to markets by value chain actors; and weak and inadequate structures and capacaties for consultation, cooperation, and coordination within the sector.
The proposed intervention is a five year programme commencing activities in September 2017 and has specific objectives linked to addressing four key agricultural value chain problems as: 1. Improved productivity of priority value chains; 2. Entepreneurial skills of priority value chain actors strengthened; 3. Access to markets by priority value chains actors improved; and 4. Structures and capacities for consultation and, collaboration, cooperation and coordination in the sector strengthened.

tag.narrative: 13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.

15.2 - By 2020, promote the implementation of sustainable management of all types of forests, halt deforestation, restore degraded forests and substantially increase afforestation and reforestation globally.

15.2 - Till 2020 främja genomförandet av hållbart brukande av alla typer av skogar, stoppa avskogningen, återställa utarmade skogar och kraftigt öka nybeskogningen och återbeskogningen i hela världen.
17.3 - Mobilisera additionella finansiella resurser till utvecklingsländerna från många olika källor.
17.3 - Mobilize additional financial resources for developing countries from multiple sources.
2.1 - By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa hunger och garantera alla människor, i synnerhet de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer, inklusive små barn, tillgång till tillräckligt med säker och näringsrik mat året om.

2.3 - By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.

2.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla jordbrukets produktivitet och inkomster för småskaliga livsmedelsproducenter, i synnerhet kvinnor, ursprungsfolk, familjejordbrukare, boskapsskötande nomader samt fiskare, inklusive genom säker och lika tillgång till mark, andra produktionsresurser och insatsvaror, kunskap, finansiella tjänster och marknader samt möjligheter till värdeskapande och sysselsättning utanför jordbruket.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
8.2 - Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value added and labour-intensive sectors.
8.2 - Uppnå högre ekonomisk produktivitet genom diversifiering, teknisk uppgradering och innovation, bland annat genom att fokusera på sektorer med högt förädlingsvärde och hög arbetsintensitet.
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation

description.narrative: The programme intensified foundational activities with development of the following key implementation tools (as results): 1. Finalization of Strategic Integrated Value Chain Action Plans (SIVCAPs) for all the counties 2. Finalization of the baseline and integration of findings into planning and results framework 3. Finalization of Gender and Sicial Inclusion survey and action plan for integration into the SIVCAPs Output level results attained within the four outcome areas are: Outcome 1. Productivity of priority value chains increased: A total of 135 opportunities were identified on increasing productivity during the report year; 1,410 innovations were identified for support; and 310 CSA and GG technologies were realised for integration into the value chains. Outcome 2. Entrepreneur skills of VCAs and service providers enhanced: 70% completion of database and 13% of the planned service providers were trained on entrepreneurial skill and 24% of the planned VCAs had viable business plans. Outcome 3: Access to market by VCAs improved: 149(16%) VCA groups were aggregated, 256(18%) market linkages established, 345 market service providers and 140,000(74%) were accessing markets. For COVID 19 adaptation, the programme facilitated the collection of food stocks data for the GoK strategic planning; policy influence and decision making with respect to realization of food and nutrition security during the pandemic period. Outcome 4, Structures and capacities for consultation, coordination and cooperation in the sector strengthened: Operationalization of 77% County Agricultural Sector Steering Committees (CASSCOMs), Capacity building of the established national, county and inter-governmental structures; 143 operational partnerships were established, 17 counties were sensitized and developed roadmaps for policy domestication in collaboration with GIZ and RTI, and 5 regulations related to the priority value chain were supported.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Kenyas regering (GoK) har bett Sverige att bidra till genomförandet av landets s.k. Vision 2030, den nya jordbrukspolicyn samt s.k. Agricultural Sector Development Strategy (ASDS 2010 – 2020) genom fortsatt finansiering till jordbrukssektorn via ASDSP programmet (Agricultural Sector Development Support Programme, fas II) under aktivitetsperioden 2017-2022 och räkenskapsåret juli 2017 till juni 2022. Kenyas egen finansiering till programmet uppgår till 2 092 500 000 KES, varav KES 1 292 500 000 kommer från landets 47 regionstyrelser och KES 800 000 000 från landets regering. Sverige har tillfrågats om att stödja programmet genom att tillhandahålla ekonomisk och teknisk hjälp motsvarande SEK 352 126 500, vilket även inkluderar EU-delegerade bidrag på SEK 52 126 500. EU-delegering baseras på positiva erfarenheter från samarbetet mellan EU, Sverige och Tyskland under fas 1 av programmet mellan 2014 och 2016. EU-överenskommelsen har gjorts i enlighet med det s.k. Action Document som gäller "stöd till jordbrukssektorns transformeringsprocess samt en decentraliserad markförvaltning". Detta godkändes av Europakommissionen 2015 (KE/FED/037-776) och finansierades genom EU-Kenya Cooperation 11th European Development Fund National Indicative Programme för perioden 2014-2020. Grunden till avtalet mellan Sverige och EU var handlingsplanen "transformation av jordbrukssektorn i Kenya", som utformades i december 2016. Planen syftar till att utveckla strukturer och kapaciteten för en bredare sektoröverskridande rådgivning och koordination på nationell, mellanstatlig och regional nivå i syfte att stärka de policies och institutioner som påverkar värdekedjornas utveckling. Resultaten för EU-delegeringen är primärt sammankopplade med ASDSP II Outcome 4. EU-bidragen är emellertid inte öronmärkta utan kommer att följas upp och rapporteras tillsammans med övriga medel.
Det föreslagna programmet är en fortsättning (fas II) av ett liknande program (ASDSP I) som avslutades i juni 2017 och som stötts och samfinansierats av Sida och Kenyas regering (huvudsakligen genom landets regering) under perioden 2012 – 2017. Enligt den interna slututvärderingen har programmet uppnått goda resultat, bland annat följande: etablerande av strukturer och institutioner som behövs för utvecklingen av tre prioriterade värdekedjor per region; introduktion och stärkande av kapacitet för att kunna utveckla värdekedjor på nya sätt där den privata sektorn och andra intressenter (huvudsakligen den privata sektorn) involveras, det har även genomförts andra värdekedjeinitiativ; man har nått ut till 563.347 värdekejdeaktörer (46 % manliga, 36 % kvinnliga och 18 % ungdomar); ökade inkomster (78 % för manliga företagare eller hushåll, 25 % för kvinnliga hushåll och 15 % för ungdomshushåll); ökad livsmedelssäkerhet från 61 %, 58 % respektive 61 % från utgångsläget 32,8 %, 38 % respektive 42 % under 2016 för manliga, kvinnliga respektive ungdomshushåll; ökad produktivitet i prioriterade värdekedjor som mejerinäring och bananodling. Utvärderingen påvisar även värdet av utvecklingsaktörer och regering att fungera som facilitatorer.
Syftet med ASDSP II är att stödja omställningen av jordbruks-, boskaps- och fiskeproduktion till kommersiellt orienterade företag för säkerställande av en hållbar livsmedels- och matförsörjning. Syftet är att utveckla prioriterade värdekedjor (VC) för sysselsättning, ökade inkomster och och förbättrad livsmedels- och matförsörjningen. Detta ska ske genom att man sammanför de olika värdekedjeaktörerna (VCA) så att utvecklingshinder kan överbryggas och värdekedjorna utvecklas på ett rättvist och hållbart sätt. ASDSP II är förankrat genom den nya jordbrukspolitiken (Agriculture Policy, AP) och bygger på resultaten från ASDSP I samt det man lärt från andra program inom denna sektor. Insatsen riktar sig till alla VCA:er, från primära producenter till konsumenter genom stöd till aktiviteter fokuserade på de fyra största utvecklingshindren: 1. Låg produktivitet längs med hela värdekedjan; 2. Otillräckliga entreprenörskunskaper bland aktörer i hela värdekedjan inklusive tjänsteleverantörer; 3. Dålig marknadstillgång för värdekedjeaktörerna; och 4. Svaga och inadekvata strukturer och kapacitet för rådgivning och koordination inom sektorn.
Insatsen förväntas bidra till till fyra övergripande resultat: 1) Ökad produktivitet för prioriterade värdekedjor; 2) Stärkt entreprenörskap hos värdekedjeaktörer (VCA); 3) Förbättrad marknadstillgång för prioriterade värdekejdeaktörer; och 4. Stärkta strukturer och kapacitet för rådgivning och samarbete inom sektorn, speciellt inom den decentraliserade strukturen. Insatsen bedöms vara en förutsättning för landsbygdens strukturomvandling eftersom den förväntas bidra till en kommersialisering av det småskaliga jordbruket.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The overall goal of ASDSP II is "to support transformation of crop, livestock and fisheries production into commercially oriented Enterprises that ensure sustainable food and nutrition security. The programme has a purpose "to develop sustainable priority value chains for improved income, employment, food and nutrition security". To attain this purpose, the programme will aim to address three main problems: Low value chain productivity; inadequate entrepreneurial skills of value chain actors; low access to markets by value chain actors; and weak and inadequate structures and capacaties for consultation, cooperation, and coordination within the sector.
The proposed intervention is a five year programme commencing activities in September 2017 and has specific objectives linked to addressing four key agricultural value chain problems as: 1. Improved productivity of priority value chains; 2. Entepreneurial skills of priority value chain actors strengthened; 3. Access to markets by priority value chains actors improved; and 4. Structures and capacities for consultation and, collaboration, cooperation and coordination in the sector strengthened.

participating-org.narrative: Other public entities in recipient country

tag.narrative: 1.2 - By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions.
1.2 - Till 2030 minst halvera den andel män, kvinnor och barn i alla åldrar som lever i någon form av fattigdom enligt nationella definitioner.
12.a - Stödja utvecklingsländerna att stärka sin vetenskapliga och tekniska kapacitet att utvecklas i riktning mot mer hållbara konsumtions- och produktionsmönster.
12.a - Support developing countries to strengthen their scientific and technological capacity to move towards more sustainable patterns of consumption and production.
13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.

2.4 - By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

2.4 - Senast 2030 uppnå hållbara system för livsmedelsproduktion samt införa motståndskraftiga jordbruksmetoder som ökar produktiviteten och produktionen, som bidrar till att upprätthålla ekosystemen, som stärker förmågan till anpassning till klimatförändringar, extrema väderförhållanden, torka, översvämning och andra katastrofer och som successivt förbättrar mark- och jordkvaliteten.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.
8.2 - Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value added and labour-intensive sectors.
8.2 - Uppnå högre ekonomisk produktivitet genom diversifiering, teknisk uppgradering och innovation, bland annat genom att fokusera på sektorer med högt förädlingsvärde och hög arbetsintensitet.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The programme intensified foundational activities with development of the following key implementation tools (as results): 1. Finalization of Strategic Integrated Value Chain Action Plans (SIVCAPs) for all the counties 2. Finalization of the baseline and integration of findings into planning and results framework 3. Finalization of Gender and Sicial Inclusion survey and action plan for integration into the SIVCAPs Output level results attained within the four outcome areas are: Outcome 1. Productivity of priority value chains increased: A total of 135 opportunities were identified on increasing productivity during the report year; 1,410 innovations were identified for support; and 310 CSA and GG technologies were realised for integration into the value chains. Outcome 2. Entrepreneur skills of VCAs and service providers enhanced: 70% completion of database and 13% of the planned service providers were trained on entrepreneurial skill and 24% of the planned VCAs had viable business plans. Outcome 3: Access to market by VCAs improved: 149(16%) VCA groups were aggregated, 256(18%) market linkages established, 345 market service providers and 140,000(74%) were accessing markets. For COVID 19 adaptation, the programme facilitated the collection of food stocks data for the GoK strategic planning; policy influence and decision making with respect to realization of food and nutrition security during the pandemic period. Outcome 4, Structures and capacities for consultation, coordination and cooperation in the sector strengthened: Operationalization of 77% County Agricultural Sector Steering Committees (CASSCOMs), Capacity building of the established national, county and inter-governmental structures; 143 operational partnerships were established, 17 counties were sensitized and developed roadmaps for policy domestication in collaboration with GIZ and RTI, and 5 regulations related to the priority value chain were supported.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Enterprise Development for Rural Families (EDRF III)
Enterprise Development for Rural Families (EDRF III)

description.narrative: EDRF III has the goal to contribute to reduction of poverty in Kenya through improved livelihoods specifically for women and youth. The intervention has the purpose to support development of profitable micro-enterprises for rural and peri-urban areas targeting the marginalized women, youth, and men. The key problems which the intervention will address within the micro-enterprise development environment as the underlying causes of poverty in the designate counties are: Low access to information; lack of entrepreneurial skills; poor access to markets; and poor access to financial services.

tag.narrative: 13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.

15.2 - By 2020, promote the implementation of sustainable management of all types of forests, halt deforestation, restore degraded forests and substantially increase afforestation and reforestation globally.

15.2 - Till 2020 främja genomförandet av hållbart brukande av alla typer av skogar, stoppa avskogningen, återställa utarmade skogar och kraftigt öka nybeskogningen och återbeskogningen i hela världen.

2.3 - By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.

2.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla jordbrukets produktivitet och inkomster för småskaliga livsmedelsproducenter, i synnerhet kvinnor, ursprungsfolk, familjejordbrukare, boskapsskötande nomader samt fiskare, inklusive genom säker och lika tillgång till mark, andra produktionsresurser och insatsvaror, kunskap, finansiella tjänster och marknader samt möjligheter till värdeskapande och sysselsättning utanför jordbruket.

2.a - Increase investment, including through enhanced international cooperation, in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services, technology development and plant and livestock gene banks in order to enhance agricultural productive capacity in developing countries, in particular least developed countries.

2.a - Öka investeringarna, bland annat genom stärkt internationellt samarbete, i infrastruktur på landsbygden, forsknings- och rådgivningstjänster för jordbruket, teknikutveckling samt genbanker för växter och husdjur i syfte att öka jordbrukets produktionskapacitet i utvecklingsländerna, i synnerhet de minst utvecklade länderna.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.

title.narrative: Agreement 51110111 Enterprise Development for Rural Families (EDRF)
Decision Enterprise development for rural families EDRF III

description.narrative: Key results for the review period include: 1. Recruitment of 4,853 members (64.3%), against an annual target of 7,540, of which 3,610 are women - 1,554 members are youth with 1,136 of these individuals being young women. 2. Establishment of 254 self-help groups (SHGs) and mobilization of SHGs into economical Community Based Organizations (CBOs) - 21 CBOs have been established with linkages to other programmes like ASDSP II for upscaling. 3. Establishment/enhancement of 507 new environmentally sustainable enterprises and cohort 2 established 2,399 giving a total of 2,906 4. Through the enterprises the members have been able to create 506 jobs under cohort 1 and 3,131 jobs under cohort 2 giving a total of 3,637 jobs. 4. Member support on COVID 19 awareness and capacity building on containment measures to ensure continued implementation of the programme
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Financial Sector Deepening Program (FSDK) finansieras gemensamt av flera givare och verkar i Kenya via en stiftelse, eller Trust. FSDK etablerades för att befrämja en utveckling av finanssektorn samt för öka fattiga människors tillgång till finansiella tjänster i Kenya. FSDK:s strategimål för 2016-2021 är att "åstadkomma varaktiga förbättringar av kenyanska låginkomsttagares levnadsförhållanden". I detta ingår att hitta möjligheter att skapa resiliens, hållbarhet och förbättrade levnadsförhållanden för låginkomsttagare. Det specifika målet är att "utveckla ett finansiellt system som skapar ett verkligt värde för låginkomsttagare i Kenya". Detta ska ske genom att samarbeta med marknadsaktörer i syfte att undanröja de hinder som finns för ett inkluderande system: 1. Hög kostnad; 2. otillräckligt värde; och 3. lågt förtroende. För att åstadkomma detta vill man bygga upp kapacitet hos aktörerna så att de kan arbeta för att undanröja hinder och hitta innovativa lösningar som kommer fattiga människor och företag till del. I detta ingår att: ändra spelreglerna och öka incitamenten för att gynna fattiga; förbättra effektiviteten inom branschen; samt befrämja en samsyn om finanssektorns utveckling.
Den reviderade budgeten, efter att DFID avbrutit sitt stöd till programmet Financial Inclusion, uppgår till 3,188 miljarder KES, varav 1,622 miljarder KES redan säkrats av Gates Foundation och 1,086 miljarder KES överförts från tidigare strategistöd (i januari 2017). Sverige ombeds bidra med 0,48 miljarder KES (50 MSEK).

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The Financial Sector Deepening (FSDK) Program is a multi-donor programme operating in Kenya through a Trust association modality. FSDK was established to facilitate the development of the financial sector and to increase the access for poor people to financial services in Kenya. FSDK Strategy 2016-2021 goal is “to generate sustainable improvements in the lives of lower-income people in Kenya” which entail seeking opportunities which build resilience, growth and improvement in quality of life for the low-income Groups. The specific objective is “to develop a financial system which delivers real value to the low-income people in Kenya”. This will be articulated through working with market players to address three key barriers to inclusion including: 1. High cost; 2. Insufficient value; and 3. Weak trust. Key approach to attainment of this is building capacity for the market to address market barriers and innovate solutions for real world needs of poor people and businesses by addressing market challenges (outcomes) which include: rules of the game (which shift incentives in favour of the poor); enhancing efficiencies in the industry infrastructure; and promoting a shared collective vision on development of the Financial Services Sector.
The revised budgetary requirement following DFID exit from support to core Financial Inclusion programme is BKES 3.188 out of which BKES 1.622 has already been secured from Gates Foundation and BKES 1.086 is a carryover from previous strategy support (as at January 2017). Sweden is requested to provide BKES 0.48 (MSEK 50).

The intervention has two components namely financial inclusion and trade facilitation. The intended outcome is to generate sustainable improvements in the lives of lower-income people in Kenya through development of a financial and trade system which delivers real value to the low-income people in Kenya. The objectives of this intervention; both financial inclusion and trade facilitation is anchored on working with market players to address three key bariers to inclusion namely i) high cost;ii) insufficient value; and iii) weak trust in the system While the specific approach to attainment of these objectives of reducing costs, creating value and building trust in both the financial and trade market system relies on building the capacity of the market to work with key areas including: rules of the game which shift incentives in favour of the poor; enhancing efficiencies in the industry infrastructure; and promoting a shared collective vision on development of the financial services sector (FSS). Additionally, trade facilitation for the real economy aims at creating market capacity and incentives to innovate trade solutions which deliver real value for the economy, enterprises and households. The rationale behind the trade facilitation is that the trade system must evolve in a way that it only allocates value to trading partners in line with the value they have added within the system and by breaking down information asymmetries.

tag.narrative: 13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.

13.3 - Förbättra utbildningen, medvetenheten och den mänskliga och institutionella kapaciteten vad gäller begränsning av klimatförändringarna, klimatanpassning, begränsning av klimatförändringarnas konsekvenser samt tidig varning.
13.3 - Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.

17.6 - Enhance North-South, South-South and triangular regional and international cooperation on and access to science, technology and innovation and enhance knowledge-sharing on mutually agreed terms, including through improved coordination among existing mechanisms, in particular at the United Nations level, and through a global technology facilitation mechanism.

17.6 - Stärka nord–syd-samarbetet, syd–syd-samarbetet och det regionala och internationella trepartssamarbetet kring och tillgången till vetenskap, teknik och innovation samt öka kunskapsutbytet på gemensamt överenskomna villkor, inklusive genom förbättrad samordning mellan befintliga mekanismer, i synnerhet på FN-nivå, och genom en global mekanism för teknikfrämjande.
2.1 - By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa hunger och garantera alla människor, i synnerhet de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer, inklusive små barn, tillgång till tillräckligt med säker och näringsrik mat året om.

2.3 - By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.

2.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla jordbrukets produktivitet och inkomster för småskaliga livsmedelsproducenter, i synnerhet kvinnor, ursprungsfolk, familjejordbrukare, boskapsskötande nomader samt fiskare, inklusive genom säker och lika tillgång till mark, andra produktionsresurser och insatsvaror, kunskap, finansiella tjänster och marknader samt möjligheter till värdeskapande och sysselsättning utanför jordbruket.

2.4 - By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

2.4 - Senast 2030 uppnå hållbara system för livsmedelsproduktion samt införa motståndskraftiga jordbruksmetoder som ökar produktiviteten och produktionen, som bidrar till att upprätthålla ekosystemen, som stärker förmågan till anpassning till klimatförändringar, extrema väderförhållanden, torka, översvämning och andra katastrofer och som successivt förbättrar mark- och jordkvaliteten.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

title.narrative: Agreement 51110111 Amendment 01 Enterprise Development for Rural Families (EDRF)
Decision Amendment 51110111 Financial Sector Deepening III

description.narrative: FSD Kenya’s projects are organised into four areas based on the financial market development outcomes outlined in its theory of change. These are: (i) Long-term vision and policy, (ii) Regulation, (iii) Financial infrastructure, and (iv) Innovation. Progress in each area and the crosscutting functions are described below. Projects under long term vision and policy included recent FSDK technical support led to the creation of a new Kenya Government Digital economy strategy blueprint (2019) launched by the Kenyan president and the recognition of Digital Finance as a flagship project highlighting the importance of the financial sector development policy (from 2005) to formally encompass financial access as a policy priority alongside efficiency and stability. A trusted partner of the National Treasury, FSD Kenya has been directly engaged in the development of successive Vision 2030 medium-term plans for the financial services sector. FSD Kenya initiated the first comprehensive market survey on financial inclusion (FinAccess Household Survey report) and supported it to becoming a sustainable part of the government statistical architecture, the study which has become the most valuable financial inclusion tracking instrument is jointly done every three years by FSDK, Central Bank of Kenya and Kenya National Bureau of Statistics . Kenya continues to be considered at the frontier in Africa, particularly given the scale and role of mobile money and fintech in both driving financial inclusion but also creating new areas of concern. Market information built on the success of the FinAccess household survey report 2019 launch garnered support for sustainability and use of FinAccess as well as the potential to complement this with the supply side data intervention. Other several successful events were held highlighting the value of segmentation and how to use data to develop more inclusive financial solutions. Under the Regulatory system development, the interest rate controls introduced in September 2016 were abolished in 2019, which is expected to have a positive impact on credit growth especially with regard to micro and small medium enterprises access to finance, financial integration and tax revenues. Additionally, work on regulation by FSD Kenya helped establish the new enabling regulatory frameworks which have underpinned the expansion of financial inclusion and fintech innovation in Kenya. This has included regulation for deposit-taking microfinance and financial co-operatives, the regulatory response which enabled the emergence of the M-Pesa mobile-money platform, agent banking, electronic payments and the first regulatory sandbox for fintech in Kenya (under the Capital Markets Authority). Under stability, the Capital Markets Authority (CMA) Sandbox continues to progress well and has inspired a promising conversation at the annual joint financial sector regulators forum about a sector-wide approach to innovation. Competition work has resulted in enhanced disclosure in both digital and non-digital realms. Reflecting Kenya’s success in encouraging the development of digital finance, regulators from across the continent and beyond have sought to learn from the Kenya approach facilitated by FSD Kenya in collaboration with the FSD Network. FinAccess Household Survey report 2019 revealed that mobile money users have substantially more challenges than users of regulated financial services like banks and mobile banks, with nearly 30% experiencing loss of money or fraud. Thus, Kenya’s financial stability is linked to innovation both in the financial sector and more broadly. The results of this work are clearly evident in the 2019 Financial Access Household Survey, where formal financial inclusion has risen from 26.7% of adults in 2006 to 82.9% in 2019, while complete exclusion of financial access and services has dropped from 41.3% of adults in 2006 to 11.0% in 2019. The informal financial sector declined from 32.1% in 2006 to 6.1% in 2019; the “excluded” category – the “unbankable” – declined from 41.3% in 2006 to 11% in 2019. PWC’s Africa Business Agenda 2019 indicated that Kenya is number 1 in Africa in the growth of innovative companies. A key area of focus going forward in Kenya will be to drive for financial stability and market integrity particularly with regards market conduct, while supporting financial innovation that drives inclusive growth. Significant gains have been achieved in improving financial infrastructure. FSD Kenya was involved in the inception of credit information sharing which now encompasses most of the formal financial system although more work is needed as credit markets continue to evolve. So far there are atleast three credit Reference Bureaus ( Credit Reference Bureau Africa Limited, Metropol Credit Reference Bureau limited and Creditinfo Credit Reference Bureau Kenya Ltd) licensed by the Central Bank of Kenya to collect and collate credit information on individuals and businesses from different sources and provide that information upon request mainly by credit providers in the form of a credit report. Support for interoperability in the payments system resulted in the creation of a new proto-national switch by the Kenya Bankers Association which has already resulted in market price improvements. This has for example resulted in scaling up of the interbank money transfer solution (PesaLink), which has moved Kenya further toward a cashless society with more financial inclusivity. FSD Kenya pioneered the use of the financial sector to deliver social protection payments in Kenya through support of the UKAid initiated Hunger Safety Net Programme and used that experience to support the launch of the government’s Inua Jamii programme in 2005 now supporting 1.2m low-income beneficiaries. Inua Jamii is owned by the Government and last year 2019 saw the close-out of Hunger Safety Net Programme (HSNP) and the government fully taking charge of the social protection programmes. Payment platforms picked up speed with progress on the National Payments System Strategy, filling key positions at Integrated Payment Services Limited (IPSL) and the Payments Association of Kenya (PAK), and initiating new work on the cash-digital interface. Aside from closing out HSNP, the rest of the Government payments work is progressing well on biometric standard interoperability, support to the Government Digital Payments (GDP) team and the ongoing support to Inua Jamii. Under Innovations, Trade facilitation and Building livelihoods both had strong progress in 2019 while the Financial innovations for the real economy (FIRE) project was on track with existing activities but behind plan on new work. The Trade project which is a public private development partnership with Kenya National Chamber of Commerce and Industry (KNCCI), Export Promotion and Brand Kenya (BrandKe), the technology provider Retail Pay Limited and the agreement partner FSDK, witnessed the full launch of the RetailPay pilot, which is a transparent system to facilitate trade end-to-end and operational support as well as key interventions initiated with consortium partners. Significant activity is underway with the Marsabit graduation pilot. The programme was initiated with the aim of testing market-based approaches to building livelihoods of very poor people; and to develop an understanding of how effectively link graduation support with market development in order to increase income and resilience among very poor households in Marsabit County, Northern Kenya. Initial results from the field monitoring visit to Marsabit (see field vist report) reveal a more positive picture about the impact of the graduation work and call into question whether the project should be closed this year or extended to ensure full sustainability. Generally, Innovation has been a centrepiece of the FSD Kenya programme from the outset and today Kenya is positioned globally as a leading innovator in financial inclusion and fintech. Direct support for the development of the Commercial Bank of Africa (CBA)/M-Pesa M-Shwari digital savings and credit solution (25.8m accounts opened since inception) has resulted in highly competitive market for digital finance. This solution has been replicated in many additional markets across Africa and beyond. Investment in establishing a novel shared management services network for 38 financial services associations (village banks) serving 300,000 low-income rural households most with no access to the formal financial service providers (except M-Pesa). FSD Kenya helped created new models to scale-up improved community-based savings groups – currently used by over one million poor households in Kenya. This work has been leveraged by other FSDs in Mozambique and Zambia. More recent work has supported experimentation with fintechs working at the intersection of finance and real-economy areas like agriculture and health. FSD Kenya’s cross-cutting functions continue to support the programme effectively. Building on the full roll-out of the project data management system, the results function supported the projects to ensure activity is aligned with objectives. Beyond the system, Results also engaged with the FSD Network process of aligning indicators on impact, carried out internal reviews through field visits and facilitated a new cross-project effort to generate case studies on the sustainability of FSD’s impact. FSD Kenya has solidified its position as the go-to source of information on financial inclusion in Kenya. In the third quarter alone of 2019, there were 62 mentions of FSD Kenya’s work in the press, 7 blogs published by the team (including one turned into an Op-ed at the request of one of the leading main stream newspapers in Kenya -Daily Nation) and increased social media engagement. According to the World Bank, it has become much easier to do business in Kenya and Kenya’s robust digital economy is mentioned as the most significant contributor to this success. In the Bank's Ease of Doing Business Index, Kenya ranked 61 out of 190 countries in 2019, up from 136 in 2015
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Financial Sector Deepening Program (FSDK) finansieras gemensamt av flera givare och verkar i Kenya via en stiftelse, eller Trust. FSDK etablerades för att befrämja en utveckling av finanssektorn samt för öka fattiga människors tillgång till finansiella tjänster i Kenya. FSDK:s strategimål för 2016-2021 är att "åstadkomma varaktiga förbättringar av kenyanska låginkomsttagares levnadsförhållanden". I detta ingår att hitta möjligheter att skapa resiliens, hållbarhet och förbättrade levnadsförhållanden för låginkomsttagare. Det specifika målet är att "utveckla ett finansiellt system som skapar ett verkligt värde för låginkomsttagare i Kenya". Detta ska ske genom att samarbeta med marknadsaktörer i syfte att undanröja de hinder som finns för ett inkluderande system: 1. Hög kostnad; 2. otillräckligt värde; och 3. lågt förtroende. För att åstadkomma detta vill man bygga upp kapacitet hos aktörerna så att de kan arbeta för att undanröja hinder och hitta innovativa lösningar som kommer fattiga människor och företag till del. I detta ingår att: ändra spelreglerna och öka incitamenten för att gynna fattiga; förbättra effektiviteten inom branschen; samt befrämja en samsyn om finanssektorns utveckling.
Den reviderade budgeten, efter att DFID avbrutit sitt stöd till programmet Financial Inclusion, uppgår till 3,188 miljarder KES, varav 1,622 miljarder KES redan säkrats av Gates Foundation och 1,086 miljarder KES överförts från tidigare strategistöd (i januari 2017). Sverige ombeds bidra med 0,48 miljarder KES (50 MSEK).

The specific objective is “to develop a financial system which delivers real value to the low-income people in Kenya”. Key approach to attainment of this is building capacity for the market to address market barriers and innovate solutions for real world needs of poor people and businesses by addressing market challenges (outcomes) which include: rules of the game (which shift incentives in favour of the poor); enhancing efficiencies in the industry infrastructure; and promoting a shared collective vision on development of the Financial Services Sector.
The revised budgetary requirement following DFID exit from support to core Financial Inclusion programme is BKES 3.188 out of which BKES 1.622 has already been secured from Gates Foundation and BKES 1.086 is a carryover from previous strategy support (as at January 2017). tag.narrative: 12.a - Stödja utvecklingsländerna att stärka sin vetenskapliga och tekniska kapacitet att utvecklas i riktning mot mer hållbara konsumtions- och produktionsmönster.
12.a - Support developing countries to strengthen their scientific and technological capacity to move towards more sustainable patterns of consumption and production.

17.16 - Enhance the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development, complemented by multi-stakeholder partnerships that mobilize and share knowledge, expertise, technology and financial resources, to support the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals in all countries, in particular developing countries

17.16 - Enhance the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development, complemented by multi-stakeholder partnerships that mobilize and share knowledge, expertise, technology and financial resources, to support the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals in all countries, in particular developing countries.
5.b - Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
5.b - Öka användningen av gynnsam teknik, i synnerhet informations- och kommunikationsteknik, för att främja kvinnors egenmakt

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

9.3 - Increase the access of small-scale industrial and other enterprises, in particular in developing countries, to financial services, including affordable credit, and their integration into value chains and markets.

9.3 - Öka tillgången för småskaliga industriföretag och andra företag, i synnerhet i utvecklingsländerna, till finansiella tjänster, inklusive överkomliga krediter, samt deras integrering i värdekedjor och marknader.

FSDK etablerades för att befrämja en utveckling av finanssektorn samt för öka fattiga människors tillgång till finansiella tjänster i Kenya. FSDK:s strategimål för 2016-2021 är att "åstadkomma varaktiga förbättringar av kenyanska låginkomsttagares levnadsförhållanden". I detta ingår att hitta möjligheter att skapa resiliens, hållbarhet och förbättrade levnadsförhållanden för låginkomsttagare. Det specifika målet är att "utveckla ett finansiellt system som skapar ett verkligt värde för låginkomsttagare i Kenya". Detta ska ske genom att samarbeta med marknadsaktörer i syfte att undanröja de hinder som finns för ett inkluderande system: 1. Hög kostnad; 2. otillräckligt värde; och 3. lågt förtroende. För att åstadkomma detta vill man bygga upp kapacitet hos aktörerna så att de kan arbeta för att undanröja hinder och hitta innovativa lösningar som kommer fattiga människor och företag till del. I detta ingår att: ändra spelreglerna och öka incitamenten för att gynna fattiga; förbättra effektiviteten inom branschen; samt befrämja en samsyn om finanssektorns utveckling.
Den reviderade budgeten, efter att DFID avbrutit sitt stöd till programmet Financial Inclusion, uppgår till 3,188 miljarder KES, varav 1,622 miljarder KES redan säkrats av Gates Foundation och 1,086 miljarder KES överförts från tidigare strategistöd (i januari 2017). Sverige ombeds bidra med 0,48 miljarder KES (50 MSEK).

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The Financial Sector Deepening (FSDK) Program is a multi-donor programme operating in Kenya through a Trust association modality. FSDK was established to facilitate the development of the financial sector and to increase the access for poor people to financial services in Kenya. FSDK Strategy 2016-2021 goal is “to generate sustainable improvements in the lives of lower-income people in Kenya” which entail seeking opportunities which build resilience, growth and improvement in quality of life for the low-income Groups. The specific objective is “to develop a financial system which delivers real value to the low-income people in Kenya”. This will be articulated through working with market players to address three key barriers to inclusion including: 1. High cost; 2. Insufficient value; and 3. Weak trust. Key approach to attainment of this is building capacity for the market to address market barriers and innovate solutions for real world needs of poor people and businesses by addressing market challenges (outcomes) which include: rules of the game (which shift incentives in favour of the poor); enhancing efficiencies in the industry infrastructure; and promoting a shared collective vision on development of the Financial Services Sector.
The revised budgetary requirement following DFID exit from support to core Financial Inclusion programme is BKES 3.188 out of which BKES 1.622 has already been secured from Gates Foundation and BKES 1.086 is a carryover from previous strategy support (as at January 2017). Sweden is requested to provide BKES 0.48 (MSEK 50).

The intervention has two components namely financial inclusion and trade facilitation. The intended outcome is to generate sustainable improvements in the lives of lower-income people in Kenya through development of a financial and trade system which delivers real value to the low-income people in Kenya. The objectives of this intervention; both financial inclusion and trade facilitation is anchored on working with market players to address three key bariers to inclusion namely i) high cost;ii) insufficient value; and iii) weak trust in the system While the specific approach to attainment of these objectives of reducing costs, creating value and building trust in both the financial and trade market system relies on building the capacity of the market to work with key areas including: rules of the game which shift incentives in favour of the poor; enhancing efficiencies in the industry infrastructure; and promoting a shared collective vision on development of the financial services sector (FSS). Additionally, trade facilitation for the real economy aims at creating market capacity and incentives to innovate trade solutions which deliver real value for the economy, enterprises and households. The rationale behind the trade facilitation is that the trade system must evolve in a way that it only allocates value to trading partners in line with the value they have added within the system and by breaking down information asymmetries.

tag.narrative: 1.a - Ensure significant mobilization of resources from a variety of sources, including through enhanced development cooperation, in order to provide adequate and predictable means for developing countries, in particular least developed countries, to implement programmes and policies to end poverty in all its dimensions.

1.a - Säkra en betydande resursmobilisering från en mängd olika källor, inklusive genom ökat utvecklingssamarbete, i syfte att ge utvecklingsländerna, i synnerhet de minst utvecklade länderna, tillräckliga och förutsebara medel för att genomföra program och politik för att avskaffa all form av fattigdom.

1.b - Create sound policy frameworks at the national, regional and international levels, based on pro-poor and gender-sensitive development strategies, to support accelerated investment in poverty eradication actions.

1.b - Upprätta sunda policyramverk på nationell, regional och internationell nivå på grundval av utvecklingsstrategier som stödjer de fattiga och tar hänsyn till jämställdhetsaspekter, för att stödja ökade investeringar i åtgärder för att avskaffa fattigdom.

2.3 - By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.

2.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla jordbrukets produktivitet och inkomster för småskaliga livsmedelsproducenter, i synnerhet kvinnor, ursprungsfolk, familjejordbrukare, boskapsskötande nomader samt fiskare, inklusive genom säker och lika tillgång till mark, andra produktionsresurser och insatsvaror, kunskap, finansiella tjänster och marknader samt möjligheter till värdeskapande och sysselsättning utanför jordbruket.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
5.b - Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
5.b - Öka användningen av gynnsam teknik, i synnerhet informations- och kommunikationsteknik, för att främja kvinnors egenmakt
5.c - Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.
5.c - Anta och stärka välgrundad politik och genomförbar lagstiftning för att främja jämställdhet och öka alla kvinnors och flickors egenmakt på alla nivåer
8.10 - Strengthen the capacity of domestic financial institutions to encourage and expand access to banking, insurance and financial services for all.
8.10 - Stärka de inhemska finansinstitutens kapacitet att främja och utöka tillgången till bank- och försäkringstjänster samt finansiella tjänster för alla.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

9.3 - Increase the access of small-scale industrial and other enterprises, in particular in developing countries, to financial services, including affordable credit, and their integration into value chains and markets.

9.3 - Öka tillgången för småskaliga industriföretag och andra företag, i synnerhet i utvecklingsländerna, till finansiella tjänster, inklusive överkomliga krediter, samt deras integrering i värdekedjor och marknader.

9.b - Stödja inhemsk teknikutveckling, forskning och innovation i utvecklingsländerna, inklusive genom att säkerställa en gynnsam policymiljö för exempelvis industriell diversifiering och förädling av råvaror.

9.b - Support domestic technology development, research and innovation in developing countries, including by ensuring a conducive policy environment for, inter alia, industrial diversification and value addition to commodities.

title.narrative: Agreement 51110111 Amendment 01 Enterprise Development for Rural Families (EDRF)
Decision Amendment 51110111 Financial Sector Deepening III

description.narrative: FSD Kenya’s projects are organised into four areas based on the financial market development outcomes outlined in its theory of change. These are: (i) Long-term vision and policy, (ii) Regulation, (iii) Financial infrastructure, and (iv) Innovation. Progress in each area and the crosscutting functions are described below. Projects under long term vision and policy included recent FSDK technical support led to the creation of a new Kenya Government Digital economy strategy blueprint (2019) launched by the Kenyan president and the recognition of Digital Finance as a flagship project highlighting the importance of the financial sector development policy (from 2005) to formally encompass financial access as a policy priority alongside efficiency and stability. A trusted partner of the National Treasury, FSD Kenya has been directly engaged in the development of successive Vision 2030 medium-term plans for the financial services sector. FSD Kenya initiated the first comprehensive market survey on financial inclusion (FinAccess Household Survey report) and supported it to becoming a sustainable part of the government statistical architecture, the study which has become the most valuable financial inclusion tracking instrument is jointly done every three years by FSDK, Central Bank of Kenya and Kenya National Bureau of Statistics . Kenya continues to be considered at the frontier in Africa, particularly given the scale and role of mobile money and fintech in both driving financial inclusion but also creating new areas of concern. Market information built on the success of the FinAccess household survey report 2019 launch garnered support for sustainability and use of FinAccess as well as the potential to complement this with the supply side data intervention. Other several successful events were held highlighting the value of segmentation and how to use data to develop more inclusive financial solutions. Under the Regulatory system development, the interest rate controls introduced in September 2016 were abolished in 2019, which is expected to have a positive impact on credit growth especially with regard to micro and small medium enterprises access to finance, financial integration and tax revenues. Additionally, work on regulation by FSD Kenya helped establish the new enabling regulatory frameworks which have underpinned the expansion of financial inclusion and fintech innovation in Kenya. This has included regulation for deposit-taking microfinance and financial co-operatives, the regulatory response which enabled the emergence of the M-Pesa mobile-money platform, agent banking, electronic payments and the first regulatory sandbox for fintech in Kenya (under the Capital Markets Authority). Under stability, the Capital Markets Authority (CMA) Sandbox continues to progress well and has inspired a promising conversation at the annual joint financial sector regulators forum about a sector-wide approach to innovation. Competition work has resulted in enhanced disclosure in both digital and non-digital realms. Reflecting Kenya’s success in encouraging the development of digital finance, regulators from across the continent and beyond have sought to learn from the Kenya approach facilitated by FSD Kenya in collaboration with the FSD Network. FinAccess Household Survey report 2019 revealed that mobile money users have substantially more challenges than users of regulated financial services like banks and mobile banks, with nearly 30% experiencing loss of money or fraud. Thus, Kenya’s financial stability is linked to innovation both in the financial sector and more broadly. The results of this work are clearly evident in the 2019 Financial Access Household Survey, where formal financial inclusion has risen from 26.7% of adults in 2006 to 82.9% in 2019, while complete exclusion of financial access and services has dropped from 41.3% of adults in 2006 to 11.0% in 2019. The informal financial sector declined from 32.1% in 2006 to 6.1% in 2019; the “excluded” category – the “unbankable” – declined from 41.3% in 2006 to 11% in 2019. PWC’s Africa Business Agenda 2019 indicated that Kenya is number 1 in Africa in the growth of innovative companies. A key area of focus going forward in Kenya will be to drive for financial stability and market integrity particularly with regards market conduct, while supporting financial innovation that drives inclusive growth. Significant gains have been achieved in improving financial infrastructure. FSD Kenya was involved in the inception of credit information sharing which now encompasses most of the formal financial system although more work is needed as credit markets continue to evolve. So far there are atleast three credit Reference Bureaus ( Credit Reference Bureau Africa Limited, Metropol Credit Reference Bureau limited and Creditinfo Credit Reference Bureau Kenya Ltd) licensed by the Central Bank of Kenya to collect and collate credit information on individuals and businesses from different sources and provide that information upon request mainly by credit providers in the form of a credit report. Support for interoperability in the payments system resulted in the creation of a new proto-national switch by the Kenya Bankers Association which has already resulted in market price improvements. This has for example resulted in scaling up of the interbank money transfer solution (PesaLink), which has moved Kenya further toward a cashless society with more financial inclusivity. FSD Kenya pioneered the use of the financial sector to deliver social protection payments in Kenya through support of the UKAid initiated Hunger Safety Net Programme and used that experience to support the launch of the government’s Inua Jamii programme in 2005 now supporting 1.2m low-income beneficiaries. Inua Jamii is owned by the Government and last year 2019 saw the close-out of Hunger Safety Net Programme (HSNP) and the government fully taking charge of the social protection programmes. Payment platforms picked up speed with progress on the National Payments System Strategy, filling key positions at Integrated Payment Services Limited (IPSL) and the Payments Association of Kenya (PAK), and initiating new work on the cash-digital interface. Aside from closing out HSNP, the rest of the Government payments work is progressing well on biometric standard interoperability, support to the Government Digital Payments (GDP) team and the ongoing support to Inua Jamii. Under Innovations, Trade facilitation and Building livelihoods both had strong progress in 2019 while the Financial innovations for the real economy (FIRE) project was on track with existing activities but behind plan on new work. The Trade project which is a public private development partnership with Kenya National Chamber of Commerce and Industry (KNCCI), Export Promotion and Brand Kenya (BrandKe), the technology provider Retail Pay Limited and the agreement partner FSDK, witnessed the full launch of the RetailPay pilot, which is a transparent system to facilitate trade end-to-end and operational support as well as key interventions initiated with consortium partners. Significant activity is underway with the Marsabit graduation pilot. The programme was initiated with the aim of testing market-based approaches to building livelihoods of very poor people; and to develop an understanding of how effectively link graduation support with market development in order to increase income and resilience among very poor households in Marsabit County, Northern Kenya. Initial results from the field monitoring visit to Marsabit (see field vist report) reveal a more positive picture about the impact of the graduation work and call into question whether the project should be closed this year or extended to ensure full sustainability. Generally, Innovation has been a centrepiece of the FSD Kenya programme from the outset and today Kenya is positioned globally as a leading innovator in financial inclusion and fintech. Direct support for the development of the Commercial Bank of Africa (CBA)/M-Pesa M-Shwari digital savings and credit solution (25.8m accounts opened since inception) has resulted in highly competitive market for digital finance. This solution has been replicated in many additional markets across Africa and beyond. Investment in establishing a novel shared management services network for 38 financial services associations (village banks) serving 300,000 low-income rural households most with no access to the formal financial service providers (except M-Pesa). FSD Kenya helped created new models to scale-up improved community-based savings groups – currently used by over one million poor households in Kenya. This work has been leveraged by other FSDs in Mozambique and Zambia. More recent work has supported experimentation with fintechs working at the intersection of finance and real-economy areas like agriculture and health. FSD Kenya’s cross-cutting functions continue to support the programme effectively. Building on the full roll-out of the project data management system, the results function supported the projects to ensure activity is aligned with objectives. Beyond the system, Results also engaged with the FSD Network process of aligning indicators on impact, carried out internal reviews through field visits and facilitated a new cross-project effort to generate case studies on the sustainability of FSD’s impact. FSD Kenya has solidified its position as the go-to source of information on financial inclusion in Kenya. In the third quarter alone of 2019, there were 62 mentions of FSD Kenya’s work in the press, 7 blogs published by the team (including one turned into an Op-ed at the request of one of the leading main stream newspapers in Kenya -Daily Nation) and increased social media engagement. According to the World Bank, it has become much easier to do business in Kenya and Kenya’s robust digital economy is mentioned as the most significant contributor to this success. In the Bank's Ease of Doing Business Index, Kenya ranked 61 out of 190 countries in 2019, up from 136 in 2015
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Financial Sector Deepening Program (FSDK) finansieras gemensamt av flera givare och verkar i Kenya via en stiftelse, eller Trust. FSDK etablerades för att befrämja en utveckling av finanssektorn samt för öka fattiga människors tillgång till finansiella tjänster i Kenya. Detta ska ske genom att samarbeta med marknadsaktörer i syfte att undanröja de hinder som finns för ett inkluderande system: 1. Hög kostnad; 2. otillräckligt värde; och 3. lågt förtroende. För att åstadkomma detta vill man bygga upp kapacitet hos aktörerna så att de kan arbeta för att undanröja hinder och hitta innovativa lösningar som kommer fattiga människor och företag till del. Den reviderade budgeten, efter att DFID avbrutit sitt stöd till programmet Financial Inclusion, uppgår till 3,188 miljarder KES, varav 1,622 miljarder KES redan säkrats av Gates Foundation och 1,086 miljarder KES överförts från tidigare strategistöd (i januari 2017). Sverige ombeds bidra med 0,48 miljarder KES (50 MSEK).

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The Financial Sector Deepening (FSDK) Program is a multi-donor programme operating in Kenya through a Trust association modality. FSDK was established to facilitate the development of the financial sector and to increase the access for poor people to financial services in Kenya. The intended outcome is to generate sustainable improvements in the lives of lower-income people in Kenya through development of a financial and trade system which delivers real value to the low-income people in Kenya. The objectives of this intervention; both financial inclusion and trade facilitation is anchored on working with market players to address three key bariers to inclusion namely i) high cost;ii) insufficient value; and iii) weak trust in the system While the specific approach to attainment of these objectives of reducing costs, creating value and building trust in both the financial and trade market system relies on building the capacity of the market to work with key areas including: rules of the game which shift incentives in favour of the poor; enhancing efficiencies in the industry infrastructure; and promoting a shared collective vision on development of the financial services sector (FSS). tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.
5.b - Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
5.b - Öka användningen av gynnsam teknik, i synnerhet informations- och kommunikationsteknik, för att främja kvinnors egenmakt
8.10 - Strengthen the capacity of domestic financial institutions to encourage and expand access to banking, insurance and financial services for all.
8.10 - Stärka de inhemska finansinstitutens kapacitet att främja och utöka tillgången till bank- och försäkringstjänster samt finansiella tjänster för alla.
8.2 - Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value added and labour-intensive sectors.
8.2 - Uppnå högre ekonomisk produktivitet genom diversifiering, teknisk uppgradering och innovation, bland annat genom att fokusera på sektorer med högt förädlingsvärde och hög arbetsintensitet.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

8.a - Increase Aid for Trade support for developing countries, in particular least developed countries, including through the Enhanced Integrated Framework for Trade-related Technical Assistance to Least Developed Countries.

8.a - Öka det handelsrelaterade stödet (Aid for Trade) till utvecklingsländerna, i synnerhet de minst utvecklade länderna, bland annat genom det förstärkta integrerade ramverket för handelsrelaterat tekniskt bistånd till de minst utvecklade länderna (Enhanced Integrated Framework for Trade-related technical Assistance to Least Developed Countries).

9.3 - Increase the access of small-scale industrial and other enterprises, in particular in developing countries, to financial services, including affordable credit, and their integration into value chains and markets.

9.3 - Öka tillgången för småskaliga industriföretag och andra företag, i synnerhet i utvecklingsländerna, till finansiella tjänster, inklusive överkomliga krediter, samt deras integrering i värdekedjor och marknader.
